metadata.@content: Nariai, Hidekazu.
Hiroshima Univ., Takehara (Japan). Research Inst. for Theoretical Physics
On characteristic turbulent quantities at the bounce epoch in our hadron-dominated model of the universe
Japan
Report
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DENSITY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; HYDRODYNAMICS; METRICS; NUCLEAR MATTER; TURBULENCE; UNIVERSE; VELOCITY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FLUID MECHANICS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATTER; MECHANICS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES

The phenomenological modification of Einstein's field equations is discussed. In a previous paper, the dynamical equations for the mean-value quantities of a turbulent field were derived. So far as the bounce epoch of the universe is concerned, three characteristic mean-value quantities <lh.lh>sub( )sup(1/2), <v2>sub( )sup(1/2), and <K2>sub( )sup(1/2) corresponding to metric, velocity, and density fluctuations are compatible with the basic idea, on two simplifying assumptions. The purpose of this note is to examine how the results obtained in the previous paper for the characteristic mean-value quantities in the bounce epoch eta=0 are modified, if one of the assumptions is replaced with a more suitable one, 4-th order approximation together with the hypothesis of joint-normal distribution. Relations in the previous paper were reduced to new forms. The numerical values of x=<lh.lh>sub( )sup(1/2), y=<K2>sub( )sup(1/2), z=<v2>sub( )sup(1/2) were obtained. It is easily seen from the results that there is considerable discrepancy between the second order solution and the 4-th order one, and that the transition to the 4-th order approximation gives smaller values of x and y, and larger values of z. (Kato, T.)
January 1974

      </availability>
    </publication>
    <classification>

      </categories>
      <descriptors>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="00681" assignment="indexer">asymptotic solutions</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02277" assignment="indexer">cosmological models</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02572" assignment="indexer">density</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03915" assignment="indexer">general relativity theory</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11998" assignment="indexer">gravitational fields</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="04547" assignment="indexer">hydrodynamics</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="indexer">metrics</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="06826" assignment="indexer">nuclear matter</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="10547" assignment="indexer">turbulence</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="10631" assignment="indexer">universe</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="10815" assignment="indexer">velocity</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03558" assignment="upposted">fluid mechanics</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11397" assignment="upposted">mathematical models</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="05913" assignment="upposted">matter</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="05945" assignment="upposted">mechanics</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="07447" assignment="upposted">physical properties</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The phenomenological modification of Einstein's field equations is discussed. In a previous paper, the dynamical equations for the mean-value quantities of a turbulent field were derived. So far as the bounce epoch of the universe is concerned, three characteristic mean-value quantities <lh.lh>sub( )sup(1/2), <v<sup>2</sup>>sub( )sup(1/2), and <K<sup>2</sup>>sub( )sup(1/2) corresponding to metric, velocity, and density fluctuations are compatible with the basic idea, on two simplifying assumptions. The purpose of this note is to examine how the results obtained in the previous paper for the characteristic mean-value quantities in the bounce epoch eta=0 are modified, if one of the assumptions is replaced with a more suitable one, 4-th order approximation together with the hypothesis of joint-normal distribution. Relations in the previous paper were reduced to new forms. The numerical values of x=<lh.lh>sub( )sup(1/2), y=<K<sup>2</sup>>sub( )sup(1/2), z=<v<sup>2</sup>>sub( )sup(1/2) were obtained. It is easily seen from the results that there is considerable discrepancy between the second order solution and the 4-th order one, and that the transition to the 4-th order approximation gives smaller values of x and y, and larger values of z. (Kato, T.)</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>
    <administratives>
      <input-center type="subj" key="JP">Japan</input-center>
      <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights>
    </administratives>
  </record>

metadata.@content: Baaklini, N.S.; Ferrara, S.; Nieuwenhuizen Van, P.
International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)
Classical solutions in supergravity
Italy
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
BOSONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; ORBITS; PRECESSION; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SYMMETRY
FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

Classical solutions of supergravity are obtained by making finite global supersymmetry rotation on known solutions of the field equations of the bosonic sector. The Schwarzschild and the Reissner-Nordstoem solutions of general relativity are extended to various supergravity systems and the modification to the perihelion precession of planets is discussed
January 1977

metadata.@content: Covarrubias, G.M. (Queen Elizabeth Coll., London (UK). Dept. of Mathematics)
Gravitational radiation in Szekeres's quasi-spherical space-times
United Kingdom
Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 13(9) p. 3023-3028; ISSN 0305-4470; Sep 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY LOSSES; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; MINKOWSKI SPACE; QUADRUPOLE MOMENTS; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; RADIATIONS; SPACE

A necessary and sufficient condition for flatness of the quasi-spherical space-times of Szekeres (Commun. Math. Phys.; 41:55 (1975) and Phys. Rev.; D12:2941 (1975)) is given. Using this, the linear approximation of these space-times is considered and it is shown that the third derivatives of the quadrupole moments vanish for matter distribution contained within a comoving surface. Hence the Einstein formula gives zero energy loss due to gravitational radiation. This agrees with other investigations, which have shown that no radiation is present in these space-times. (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Smith, A.G.; Will, C.M. (Institute of Theoretical Physics, Department of Physics, Stanford University, Stanford, California 94305)
Force on a static charge outside a Schwarzschild black hole
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 22(6) p. 1276-1284; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Sep 1980
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

BLACK HOLES; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; CHARGED PARTICLES; COULOMB FIELD; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROSTATICS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GREEN FUNCTION; MASS RENORMALIZATION; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SCHWARZSCHILD RADIUS; SPACE-TIME
ELECTRIC FIELDS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; RENORMALIZATION

An exact calculation of the gravitationally induced electrostatic self-force on a charged test particle held stationary outside a Schwarzschild black hole is presented. After mass renormalization, there remains a finite repulsive force proportional to the square of the charge of the particle and to the mass of the black hole. In a local, freely falling frame momentarily at rest with respect to the charge, the repulsive force varies as the inverse cube of the Schwarzschild coordinate distance of the charge from the origin
January 1980

metadata.@content: Dray, T.; Walker, M. (Max-Planck-Institut fuer Physik und Astrophysik, Garching (Germany, F.R.). Inst. fuer Astrophysik)
On the regularity of Ernst's generalized C-metric
Netherlands
Letters in Mathematical Physics; v. 4(1) p. 15-18; ISSN 0377-9017; Jan 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ACCELERATION; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS
We establish the regularity of Ernst's generalized C-metric, thus reinforcing his interpretation of its as a pair of black holes being accelerated in an external gravitational field. (orig.)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Bejlin, V.A.; Vereshkov, G.M.; Grishkan, Yu.S.; Ivanov, N.M.; Nesterenko, V.A.; Poltavtsev, A.N. (Rostovskij-na-Donu Gosudarstvennyj Univ. (USSR). Nauchno-Issledovatel'skij Inst. Fiziki)
On quantum gravitational effects in an isotropic Universe
O kvantovykh gravitatsionnykh ehffektakh v izotropnoj vselennoj
Russian
USSR
Zhurnal Ehksperimental'noj i Teoreticheskoj Fiziki; v. 78(6) p. 2081-2098; ISSN 0044-4510; Jun 1980; For English translation see the journal Soviet Physics - JETP (USA).
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENTROPY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; ISOTROPY; PARTICLE PRODUCTION; PERTURBATION THEORY; QUANTUM GRAVITY; RADIATIVE CORRECTIONS; RELATIVISTIC RANGE; UNIVERSE; VACUUM POLARIZATION
CORRECTIONS; ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTERACTIONS; PARTICLE INTERACTIONS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES

Vacuum polarization effects induced by an external gravitational field in a systeM of spjnor, scalar or vector mass particles are considered on the basis of the model of conformally-plane time-space. Expressions for the radiative corrections are obtained and the role they play in the theory of gravitation in the asymptotic regions of weak (|Rsub(i)sup(k)|<<msup(2)) and strong (|Rsub(i)sup(k)|>>msup(2)) gravitational fields is analyzed. Formulae for the rate of spontaneous production of real particles by a strong gravitational field are presented in the Appendix as well as formulae for the energy-momentum tensor for real particles in the ultrarelativistic limit. The law of increase of entropy in an ultrarelativistic medium is formulated
January 1980

        <descriptor type="valid" key="10060" assignment="upposted">thermodynamic properties</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">Vacuum polarization effects induced by an external gravitational field in a systeM of spjnor, scalar or vector mass particles are considered on the basis of the model of conformally-plane time-space. Expressions for the radiative corrections are obtained and the role they play in the theory of gravitation in the asymptotic regions of weak (|Rsub(i)sup(k)|<<msup(2)) and strong (|Rsub(i)sup(k)|>>msup(2)) gravitational fields is analyzed. Formulae for the rate of spontaneous production of real particles by a strong gravitational field are presented in the Appendix as well as formulae for the energy-momentum tensor for real particles in the ultrarelativistic limit. The law of increase of entropy in an ultrarelativistic medium is formulated</abstract>
      </abstracts>

metadata.@content: Ipser, J.R. (University of Chicago)
Binding-energy criterion for the dynamical stability of spherical stellar systems in general relativity
United States
Astrophysical Journal; v. 238(3) p. 1101-1110; ISSN 0004-637X; 15 Jun 1980
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
BINDING ENERGY; DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; DISTRIBUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUILIBRIUM; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; STABILITY; STAR CLUSTERS
CONFIGURATION; ENERGY; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

A powerful sufficient condition for the dynamical stability of spherical stellar systems to collisionless spherical perturbations is derived within the framework of general relativity. The derivation proceeds along lines similar to those of an earlier paper devoted to the corresponding Newtonian problem. It begins with the formulation of, and solution to, the problem of determining which relativistic spherical systems maximize locally, at fixed mass-energy, rest mass, and boundary value of the phase density, the value of the phase-space integral of a chosen function of the phase density. It is shown that members of appropriate one-parameter sequences of spherical equilibria cease to maximize their associated integral-functionals at the first maxima of the binding energy along the sequences. A proof is given that a relativistic spherical stellar system in collisionless equilibrium is dynamically stable to collisionless perturbations if it does maximize the unique functional which it extremizes. This implies that members of appropriate equilibrium sequences are stable at least up to the first maximum of the binding energy. This sufficient condition is remarkably strong, because in several studied cases it breaks down at a point which coincides, to within available numerical accuracy, with the calculated point of onset of dynamical instability. This leads to the conjecture that the condition is in fact also generally necessary. If so, an implication would be that general relativity induces spherical dynamical instabilities in certain nearly Newtonian stellar systems. While conceptually important, this would probably be of limited astrophysical interest, since the instability growth times should be quite long

f so, an implication would be that general relativity induces spherical dynamical instabilities in certain nearly Newtonian stellar systems. While conceptually important, this would probably be of limited astrophysical interest, since the instability growth times should be quite long
January 1980

metadata.@content: Lapedes, A.S. (Institute for Advanced Study, School of Natural Sciences, Princeton, New Jersey 08540)
Black-hole uniqueness theorems in Euclidean quantum gravity
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 22(8) p. 1837-1847; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Oct 1980
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
BLACK HOLES; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EUCLIDEAN SPACE; FEYNMAN PATH INTEGRAL; KERR METRIC; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SCHWARZSCHILD RADIUS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTEGRALS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE

The Euclidean section of the classical Lorentzian black-hole solutions has been used in approximating the functional integral in the Euclidean path-integral approach to quantum gravity. In this paper the claim that classical black-hole uniqueness theorems apply to the Euclidean section is disproved. In particular, it is shown that although a Euclidean version of Israel's theorem does provide a type of uniqueness theorem for the Euclidean Schwarzschild solution, a Euclidean version of Robinson's theorem does not allow one to form conclusions about the uniqueness of the Euclidean Kerr solution. Despite the failure of uniqueness theorems, ''no-hair'' theorems are shown to exist. Implications are discussed. A precise mathematical statement of the Euclidean black-hole uniqueness conjecture is made and the proof, left as an unsolved problem in Riemannian geometry
January 1980

metadata.@content: Galloway, A.J. (Queen Elizabeth Coll., London (UK). Dept. of Mathematics)
On Nariai's boundary condition in general relativity
Japan
Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 63(1) p. 140-145; ISSN 0033-068X; Jan 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; SINGULARITY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

In 1965 Nariai suggested that the boundary conditions of O'Brien and Synge should be supplemented by an extra equation. It is shown here that Nariai's extra equation reduces to an identity if the O'Brien and Synge boundary conditions are applied. (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Chandrasekhar, S. (Chicago Univ., IL (USA))
The general theory of relativity: the first thirty years
United Kingdom
Contemporary Physics; v. 21(5) p. 429-449; ISSN 0010-7514; Sep - Oct 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; REVIEWS; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC
DOCUMENT TYPES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

The principal landmarks in the development of general relativity (exclusive of cosmology) during the first 30 years after its founding are presented. The emergence of the new gravitational laws, their experimental consequences and the consequent growth of the present concern with gravitational collapse and black holes are traced. (U.K.)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Durgapal, M.C.; Rawat, P.S.; Bannerji, R. (Kumaun Univ., Naini Tal (India). Dept. of Physics)
Structures with extreme relativistic cores
United Kingdom
Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 13(12) p. 3761-3768; ISSN 0305-4470; Dec 1980
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; DISTRIBUTION FUNCTIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; ISOTHERMAL PROCESSES; MASS; NEUTRON STARS; RED SHIFT; STAR MODELS; THEORETICAL DATA
DATA; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INFORMATION; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NUMERICAL DATA; STARS

The structures of isothermal cores with extreme relativistic conditions are discussed and central redshifts calculated for polytropic envelopes which have positive distribution function for all possible energies provided that dp/drho<= 1. Choosing an envelope in which the density is a specific function of r and assuming the surface density to be equal to 2 x 1014 g cm-3, the mass of neutron stars has been calculated. The maximum mass of 4.7 Solar Masses is consistent with the results of other authors. (U.K.)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Freund, P.G.O.; Rubin, M.A. (Chicago Univ., IL (USA). Enrico Fermi Inst.; Chicago Univ., IL (USA). Dept. of Physics)
Dynamics of dimensional reduction
Netherlands
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; SUPERGRAVITY; TENSORS; UNIFIED GAUGE MODELS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

In d-dimensional unified theories that, along with gravity, contain an antisymmetric tensor field of rank s-1, preferential compactification of d-s or of s space-like dimensions is found to occur. This is the case in 11-dimensional supergravity where s = 4. (orig.)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Maeda, Keiichi (Kyoto Univ. (Japan). Research Inst. for Fundamental Physics)
Gravitational collapse of charged dust shell and maximal slicing condition
Japan
Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 63(2) p. 425-437; ISSN 0033-068X; Feb 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
DUSTS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MASS; METRICS; SHELLS; THEORETICAL DATA
DATA; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA

The maximal slicing condition is a good time coordinate condition qualitatively when pursuing the gravitational collapse by the numerical calculation. The analytic solution of the gravitational collapse under the maximal slicing condition is given in the case of a spherical charged dust shell and the behavior of time slices with this coordinate condition is investigated. It is concluded that under the maximal slicing condition we can pursue the gravitational collapse until the radius of the shell decreases to about 0.7 x (the radius of the event horizon). (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Beig, R.; Simon, W. (Vienna Univ. (Austria). Inst. fuer Theoretische Physik)
Proof of a multipole conjecture due to Geroch
Germany
Communications in Mathematical Physics; v. 78(1) p. 75-82; ISSN 0010-3616; Nov 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
CONFORMAL MAPPING; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MULTIPOLES; POTENTIAL ENERGY; RIEMANN SPACE; SMOOTH MANIFOLDS; SPACE-TIME
ENERGY; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE; TOPOLOGICAL MAPPING; TRANSFORMATIONS

A result, first conjectured by Geroch, is proved to the extent, that the multipole moments of a static space-time characterize this space-time uniquely. As an offshoot of the proof one obtains an essentially coordinate-free algorithm for explicitly writing down a geometry in terms of it's moments in a purely algebraic manner. This algorithm seems suited for symbolic manipulation on a computer. (orig.)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Centrella, J. (Institute of Astronomy, Cambridge, England)
Interacting gravitational shocks in vacuum plane-symmetric cosmologies
United States
Astrophysical Journal; v. 241(3) p. 875-885; ISSN 0004-637X; 1 Nov 1980
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
COMPUTER CODES; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; DATA PROCESSING; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; METRICS; SHOCK WAVES; SPACE-TIME; WAVE PROPAGATION
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

Gravitational shocks in vacuum cosmological models are studied numerically. We follow the free propagation of the shocks, including the formation of tails behind the shocks and their collisional interactions

metadata.@content: Kay, B.S. (Princeton Univ., NJ (USA). Inst. for Advanced Study; Imperial Coll. of Science and Technology, London (UK). Blackett Lab.; Bern Univ. (Switzerland). Inst. fuer Theoretische Physik)
In-out semi-classical gravity and 1/N quantum gravity
Netherlands
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FEYNMAN DIAGRAM; MATRIX ELEMENTS; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SEMICLASSICAL APPROXIMATION; TENSORS
DIAGRAMS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INFORMATION; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

Classical gravity with higher derivatives, when coupled to the in-out matrix element of Tsub()sub(): (a) appears to be free from instabilities of the in-in theory; (b) may be considered as the underlying classical theory to Tomboulis' 1/N-resummed quantum gravity. I explain how these two facts may be adduced as evidence for the viability both of the former semi-classical approximation and of the latter approach to full quantum gravity. (orig.)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Kodama, Hideo (Kyoto Univ. (Japan). Dept. of Physics)
Conserved energy flux for the spherically symmetric system and the backreaction problem in the black hole evaporation
Japan
Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 63(4) p. 1217-1228; ISSN 0033-068X; Apr 1980
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
BLACK HOLES; CONSERVATION LAWS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EVAPORATION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; RADIATION FLUX; SINGULARITY; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION
CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS

For the spherically symmetric system, we prove the existence of a new locally conserved flux which can be interpreted to represent the total energy flux of matter and gravitational field. With the aid of this conservation law, we study the relation between the behavior of the event horizon and the energy flux across it and look for constraints imposed on the total energy radiated to infinity. Some implications of the results of this study to the backreaction problem in the black hole evaporation are discussed. (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Xanthopoulos, B.C. (Department of Physics, Syracuse University, Syracuse, New York 13210)
Exterior spacetimes for rotating stars
United States
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ALGORITHMS; ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; AXIAL SYMMETRY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; MULTIPOLES; SPACE-TIME; WEYL UNIFIED THEORY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; SYMMETRY

The algorithms are studied which construct stationary axisymmetric asymptotically flat spacetimes. The multipole moment structure of the resulting spacetimes is determined. The static metric and the transformations which generate any stationary metric are obtained
January 1981

metadata.@content: Hiscock, W.A. (Physics Department, Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut 06520)
Models of evaporating black holes. I
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 23(12) p. 2813-2822; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Jun 1981
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EVAPORATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; METRICS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; SCALAR FIELDS; SCHWARZSCHILD RADIUS; SPACE-TIME
ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; SPACE

Classical spacetimes which contain evaporating black holes (EBH's) are constructed using the Vaidya metric. These model EBH spacetimes are spherically symmetric, asymptotically flat, and contain event horizons which terminate after finite duration. These model EBH spacetimes are then used as fixed backgrounds for particle-creation calculations, in an attempt to learn something of the dynamics of real, semiclassical EBH spacetimes while bypassing the difficulties associated with the back-reaction problem. The stress-energy tensor of a quantized massless scalar field is studied on the two-dimensional EBH spacetimes obtained by setting dtheta = dphi = 0. If lim(dM/dv)not =0 as M0 (v the usual ingoing null coordinate), then an infinite flux of outgoing radiation is produced along the Cauchy horizon of the EBH. This behavior suggests that a correct, self-consistent semiclassical EBH spacetime must have lim(dM/dv) = 0 as M0, contrary to the behavior deduced by naively extrapolating Hawking's result all the way down to M = 0, which gives dM/dvapprox.M-2. It also shows that not all zero-mass naked singularities left at the end point of an evaporating black hole are benign; they may produce a divergent flux of created particles
January 1981

        <descriptor type="valid" key="05907" assignment="upposted">mathematical space</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="07329" assignment="upposted">phase transformations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09317" assignment="upposted">space</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">Classical spacetimes which contain evaporating black holes (EBH's) are constructed using the Vaidya metric. These model EBH spacetimes are spherically symmetric, asymptotically flat, and contain event horizons which terminate after finite duration. These model EBH spacetimes are then used as fixed backgrounds for particle-creation calculations, in an attempt to learn something of the dynamics of real, semiclassical EBH spacetimes while bypassing the difficulties associated with the back-reaction problem. The stress-energy tensor of a quantized massless scalar field is studied on the two-dimensional EBH spacetimes obtained by setting dtheta = dphi = 0. If lim(dM/dv)not =0 as M0 (v the usual ingoing null coordinate), then an infinite flux of outgoing radiation is produced along the Cauchy horizon of the EBH. This behavior suggests that a correct, self-consistent semiclassical EBH spacetime must have lim(dM/dv) = 0 as M0, contrary to the behavior deduced by naively extrapolating Hawking's result all the way down to M = 0, which gives dM/dvapprox.M<sup>-2</sup>. It also shows that not all zero-mass naked singularities left at the end point of an evaporating black hole are benign; they may produce a divergent flux of created particles</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>
    <administratives>
      <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center>
      <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights>
    </administratives>
  </record>
</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: Papadopoulos, D.; Stewart, B.; Witten, L. (Department of Physics, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, Ohio 45221)
Some properties of a particular static, axially symmetric space-time
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 24(2) p. 320-326; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Jul 1981
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; WEYL UNIFIED THEORY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; SPACE

The behavior of the directional singularities of a family of Weyl solutions is examined. By examining the space-time in a different coordinate system, the directional singularities are understood. The singular points are actually extended hypersurfaces which have been collapsed to a point by an improper choice of coordinates. The singular structure is examined in the new coordinate system. The coordinate system shows the space-time to be geodesically incomplete. A completion of the symmetry axis is described
January 1981

metadata.@content: Barger, V.; Whisnant, K.; Phillips, R.J.N. (Physics Department, University of Wisconsin: Madison, Madison, Wisconsin 53706)
Realistic calculations of solar-neutrino oscillations
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 24(2) p. 538-541; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Jul 1981
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; WEYL UNIFIED THEORY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; SPACE

We reexamine the possible effects of oscillations on the apparent solar-neutrino flux, integrated over the theoretical solar spectrum weighted by the 37Cl or 71Ga neutrino capture cross section. Spectral, thermal, and distance averaging do not reduce all oscillations to their mean values. The averaged /sub e//sub e/ transition probability can fall as low as 0.1. Annual variations are evaluated
January 1981

metadata.@content: Chinea, F.J. (Departamento de Fisica Fundamental, U.N.E.D., Madrid, Spain)
Integrability formulation and Baecklund transformations for gravitational fields with symmetries
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 24(4) p. 1053-1055; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Aug 1981
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; SCHROEDINGER EQUATION; SO GROUPS; SU-2 GROUPS
DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; SU GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

The Ernst equation for gravitational fields with a two-parameter isometry group is formulated as a vanishing-curvature condition on an SU(2) or SU(1,1) bundle, both in the elliptic and hyperbolic cases. Baecklund transformations are introduced as a special case of gauge transformations, and strong Baecklund transformations are obtained in that context
January 1981

metadata.@content: Kleber, A. (Observatorio Nacional, Rio de Janeiro (Brazil)); Fonseca Teixeira, A.F. da (Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Fisicas, Rio de Janeiro)
Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Fisicas, Rio de Janeiro
Gravitational peculiarities of a scalar field
Brazil
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
AXIAL SYMMETRY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; METRICS; ORBITS; SCALAR FIELDS; SPACE-TIME; THEORETICAL DATA
DATA; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INFORMATION; NUMERICAL DATA; SYMMETRY

The zero-adjoint of a time-static Ricci-flat solution to Einstein's field equations is investigated. It represents a spacetime curved solely by a massless scalar field. The cylindrical symmetry is assumed to permit both planar and non-planar geodetic motions. Unusual, velocity-dependent gravitational features are encountered from these geodesics. (Author)
January 1979

metadata.@content: Hu, B.L. (Maryland Univ., College Park (USA). Dept. of Physics and Astronomy)
Effect of the finite-temperature quantum fields on the early universe
Netherlands
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SCALAR FIELDS; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES

The finite-temperature effect of a quantized conformally invariant scalar field in a closed Robertson-Walker universe is studied. The general solution is characterized by one parameter xi = Ta which measures the radiation content of the universe. In the high-temperature limit it reduces to the Fischetti-Hartle-Hu solution where the universe expands linearly in cosmic time near the singularity. In the low-temperature limit, it reduces to a Starobinsky-de Sitter type solution where the singularity is avoided in an exponential expansion. Several characteristic functional dependences of (t) are used to illustrate possible entropy generating processes. The finite-temperature formalism thus provides a unifying framework for the description of the interplay of vacuum and radiation energy and their combined effect on the state of the early universe. (orig.)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Schendel, J.; Winicour, J. (Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 15260)
Restrictions on relativistically rotating fluids
United States
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUIDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; KERR METRIC; QUASARS; RED SHIFT; ROTATION
COSMIC RADIO SOURCES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

We develop an extensive set of inequalities which apply to the surface of a relativistically rotating fluid with asymptotically flat exterior. We explore the physical content of these inequalities by examining the restrictions they impose on the existence of rotating fluid models with Kerr exteriors. In that case, the dominant set of inequalities can be expressed in a simple analytic form. We find for all models with Kerr parameter a>m that there is a finite maximum redshift between observers at the fluid surface and at infinity. However, for all models with 0<a/m< or =1 there is no upper bound to the redshift. In the static limit, as a/m0, a finite redshift maximum emerges in a discontinuous manner. The value of this maximum depends upon the moment of inertia of the static background fluid. We discuss the implications toward the possibility of a high redshift quasar model
January 1981

metadata.@content: Beig, R. (Vienna Univ. (Austria). Inst. fuer Theoretische Physik)
The multipole expansion in general relativity
Austria
Acta Physica Austriaca; v. 53(4) p. 249-270; ISSN 0001-6713; 1981
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; METRICS; MULTIPOLES; SPACE-TIME; VECTOR FIELDS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

A recently undertaken study of multipole moments in General Relativity is completed and different approaches summarized in a unified manner. Among the new results in this paper is a treatment of the behaviour of the multipole moments under finite translations and generalizations of the notion of a centre of mass (charge) to the case, when the mass is zero. Furthermore the author studies the dependence of the multipoles on the choice of the potential. (Auth.)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Mamaev, S.G. (Leningradskij Ehlektrotekhnicheskij Inst. (USSR))
Quantum effects in cosmological models with singularities
Kvantovye ehffekty v kosmologicheskikh modelyakh s singulyarnostyami
Russian
USSR
Izvestiya Vysshikh Uchebnykh Zavedenij, Fizika; v. 24(1) p. 67-70; ISSN 0021-3411; 1981; For English translation see the journal Soviet Physics Journal (USA).
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DE SITTER GROUP; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EXPECTATION VALUE; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; RENORMALIZATION; SCALAR FIELDS; SINGULARITY; SPINOR FIELDS; VACUUM STATES
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

Accurate calculation of vacuum averages of energy-pulse tensor of quantum scalar and spin fields in de Sitter space of the first kind, is conducted by the regularization method. Limiting cases of the obtained accurate expressions are considered. It is noted, that space of the Sitter is a self-agreeable solution of Einstein equation with account of quantum fluctuations of vacuum of non-massive fields
January 1981

metadata.@content: Sanchez-Velasco, E. (Universidad Autonoma de Madrid (Spain). Dept. de Fisica Teorica)
The trace anomaly in coloured black holes
Netherlands
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; BAG MODEL; BLACK HOLES; COLOR MODEL; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTRIC FIELDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MAGNETIC FIELDS; METRICS; PHASE TRANSFORMATIONS; SPACE-TIME; TENSORS; UNIFIED GAUGE MODELS; YANG-MILLS THEORY
COMPOSITE MODELS; EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; QUARK MODEL

The influence of the trace anomaly of the energy-momentum tensor of gauge theories is discussed in a spherically symmetric space-time. It is found that for pure electric and magnetic fields, the point (g) = -g represents a phase transition from an asymptotically flat metric to an asymptotically non-flat metric which turns out to be confining in the electric case. (orig.)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Agakov, V.G. (Moskovskij Gosudarstvennyj Univ. (USSR). Gosudarstvennyj Astronomicheskij Inst. ''GAISh'')
Regular minimum of the scale factor of co-moving space in general relativity theory
Regulyarnyj minimum masshtabnogo faktora soputstvuyushchego prostranstva v teorii tyagoteniya Ejnshtejna
Russian
USSR
Vestnik Moskovskogo Universiteta, Seriya 3. Fizika, Astronomiya; v. 22(3) p. 49-54; ISSN 0579-9392; Mar - Apr 1981; For English translation see the journal Moscow University Physics Bulletin (USA).
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SINGULARITY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; SPACE

Existence of an analytical solution of the Einstein equation containing the maximum number of physically arbitrary functions, in which the R scale factor of co-moving space passes through the regular minimum corresponding to the finite density, is shown. The cases of ideal and viscous medium under conditions of full assignment of the law of viscosity are considered. Near the regular R minimum the character of deformation of co-moving space, volume and density variations of ideal and viscous medium are considered
January 1981

metadata.@content: Semenzato, R.; Ipser, J.R. (The University of Chicago)
Odd-parity pertubations of spherically symmetric star clusters in general relativity
United States
Astrophysical Journal; v. 247(2) p. 671-676; ISSN 0004-637X; 15 Jul 1981
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
DISTURBANCES; EIGENFREQUENCY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; INSTABILITY; OSCILLATION MODES; PARITY; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; STAR CLUSTERS; SYMMETRY; TENSORS
CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; PARTICLE PROPERTIES

The theory of odd-parity nonspherical peturbations of collisionless, isotropic, spherically symmetric star clusters is developed within general relativity for l> or =2. A variational principle is derived for the associated normal modes of oscillation. The variational expression reveals that an unstable normal mode has a pure exponentially growing time dependence--the corresponding complex ''eigenfrequency'' is purely imaginary--and hence that a normal mode can become unstable in a smooth fashion only thorugh zero frequency. Further, it is shown that no instabilities can set in through zero-frequency modes along smooth sequences of models with fewer high-energy stars than low-energy stars. Unless unstable normal modes suddenly appear in a nonsmooth fashion, the implications is that these models possess no unstable normal modes
January 1981

metadata.@content: Ikeda, S. (Science Univ. of Tokyo, Noda, Chiba (Japan). Faculty of Science and Technology)
Some physico-geometrical remarks on the relationship between the micro- and macro-gravitational fields
Italy
Lettere al Nuovo Cimento; v. 25(1) p. 21-25; ISSN 0024-1318; 5 May 1979
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MATHEMATICS; SPACE-TIME; TENSORS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

Under the premise that the micro-gravitational field has a Finslerian structure due to the space-time fluctuation (xi), some ''non''-Riemannian features underlying the macro-gravitational field are investigated. And the averaging process with respect to xi is reconsidered from the standpoint of geometrical thermodynamics. (author)
January 1979

metadata.@content: Goode, S.W.; Wainwright, J. (Waterloo Univ., Ontario (Canada). Dept. of Applied Mathematics)
Friedmann-like singularities in Szekeres' cosmological models
United Kingdom
Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society; v. 198(1) p. 83-90; ISSN 0035-8711; Jan 1982
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; SINGULARITY; TENSORS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

The existence is established of Friedmann-like singularities in a subclass of the Szekeres cosmological models which admits no Killing vector fields, and which depends on three arbitrary functions of a single variable. The asymptotic properties of the solutions are described as the singularity is approached, for example the behaviour of the matter density, the rate of shear of the matter, and the Weyl conformal curvature tensor. The solutions are formulated in a way which permits comparison with linear perturbations of the Einstein-de Sitter solution. (author)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Berger, B.K. (California Univ., Santa Barbara (USA). Inst. for Theoretical Physics; Oakland Univ., Rochester, MI (USA). Dept. of Physics)
Singularity avoidance in the semi-classical Gowdy T3 cosmological model
Netherlands
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SECOND QUANTIZATION; SEMICLASSICAL APPROXIMATION; SINGULARITY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

The spatially averaged semi-classical Gowdy T3 cosmological model is constructed and evolved self-consistently. It is shown that quantum effects replace the classically present singularity with a symmetric bounce. (orig.)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Schaefer, G. (Fakultaet fuer Physik der Universitaet Konstanz, Federal Republic of Germany)
Gravitational quadrupole formulae and gravitationally bound matter systems
United States
Astrophysical Journal, Letters to the Editor; v. 249(3) p. L5-L8; ISSN 0571-7248; 1 Nov 1981
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; METRICS; VIRIAL THEOREM
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; RADIATIONS

For gravitationally bound matter systems, a new approach to the gravitational quadrupole radiation problem is presented. It simultaneously gives the energy loss rate at infinity and the radiation-reaction force on the matter system, without using singular asymptotic expansions and without encountering long-range divergences. The quadrupole formulae are confirmed
January 1981

The quadrupole formulae are confirmed</abstract>

metadata.@content: Michel, F.C. (Space Physics and Astronomy Department, Rice University, Houston, Texas)
Theory of pulsar magnetospheres
United States
Reviews of Modern Physics; v. 54(1) p. 1-66; ISSN 0034-6861; Jan 1982
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

CHERENKOV RADIATION; COSMIC GAMMA BURSTS; COSMIC GAMMA SOURCES; COSMIC RADIATION; COSMIC RADIO SOURCES; COSMIC RAY SOURCES; COSMIC X-RAY SOURCES; CRAB NEBULA; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTRIC CURRENTS; ELECTROMAGNETIC INTERACTIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC PARTICLE DECAY; ELECTROMAGNETIC PULSES; ENERGY SPECTRA; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; GRAVITATIONAL INTERACTIONS; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; LIGHT CONE; LIGHT SOURCES; LUMINOSITY; MAGNETIC FIELD CONFIGURATIONS; MAGNETIC FIELDS; MAGNETIC MOMENTS; MAGNETIC MONOPOLES; MAGNETIC SURFACES; MASERS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NEUTRINOS; NEUTRON STARS; NEUTRONS; OSCILLATIONS; PAIR PRODUCTION; PARTICLE MODELS; PARTICLE PRODUCTION; PHOTONS; PLASMA SHEET; POLARIZATION; PULSARS; PULSATIONS; PULSE RISE TIME; PULSES; QUASARS; RELATIVITY THEORY; REVIEWS; ROTATIONAL TRANSFORM; SLOWING-DOWN; STAR EVOLUTION; STAR MODELS; STELLAR FLARES; STELLAR MAGNETOSPHERES; STELLAR WINDS; STIMULATED EMISSION; SUPERNOVA REMNANTS; X RADIATION

AMPLIFIERS; ATMOSPHERES; BARYONS; BASIC INTERACTIONS; CURRENTS; DECAY; DOCUMENT TYPES; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; ELECTRONIC EQUIPMENT; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EMISSION; ENERGY-LEVEL TRANSITIONS; EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; HADRONS; INTERACTIONS; IONIZING RADIATIONS; LEPTONS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MICROWAVE AMPLIFIERS; MICROWAVE EQUIPMENT; MONOPOLES; NEBULAE; NUCLEONS; OPTICAL PROPERTIES; PARTICLE DECAY; PARTICLE INTERACTIONS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; POSTULATED PARTICLES; PRIMARY COSMIC RADIATION; RADIATION SOURCES; RADIATIONS; SPACE-TIME; SPECTRA; STARS; STELLAR ATMOSPHERES; TIMING PROPERTIES

There is a wide range of fundamental physical problems directly related to how pulsars function. Some of these are independent of the specific pulsar mechanism. Others relate directly to the physics of the pulsar and already shed some light on the properties of matter at high density (approx.1015 g/cc) and in strong magnetic fields (approx.1012 G). Pulsars are assumed to be rotating neutron stars surrounded by strong magnetic fields and energetic particles. It is somewhere within this ''magnetosphere'' that the pulsar action is expected to take place. Currently there has been considerable difficulty in formulating an entirely self-consistent theory of the magnetospheric behavior and there may be rapid revisions in the near future, which is all the more surprising since many of the issues involve ''elementary'' problems in electromagnetism. One interesting discovery is that charge-separated plasmas apparently can support stable static discontinuities
January 1982

metadata.@content: Howes, R.J. (La Trobe Univ., Bundoora (Australia). Dept. of Mathematics)
Effects of a positive cosmological constant on circular orbits in the Reissner-Nordstroem, Schwarzschild, and Kerr fields
United States
General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 13(9) p. 829-835; ISSN 0001-7701; Sep 1981
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
CIRCULAR CONFIGURATION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNDAMENTAL CONSTANTS; GEODESICS; KERR FIELD; ORBIT STABILITY; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC
CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; METRICS; STABILITY

Criteria for the existence and stability of circular orbits in a general stationary axisymmetric field are established using the equation of geodesic deviation. Circular orbits in the Reissner-Nordstrom, Schwarzschild and Kerr fields, all with a positive cosmological constant  included, are considered and the effects of  are detailed. (author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Unwin, S.D. (Newcastle upon Tyne Univ. (UK). Dept. of Theoretical Physics)
Twisted symmetry breaking on the projective hypersphere: a model of the small cosmological constant
United Kingdom
Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 15(3) p. 841-848; ISSN 0305-4470; Mar 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GOLDSTONE BOSONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; SCALAR FIELDS; SPACE-TIME; SYMMETRY BREAKING; VACUUM STATES
BOSONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; POSTULATED PARTICLES

A model is considered in which the gravitational action effectively depends upon the symmetry-broken vacuum state associated with a twisted scalar field theory. It is suggested that the observation of a small cosmological constant, despite predicted vacuum contributions typically of the order 10-6 cm-2, is a consequence of our location in the universe. (author)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Laurent, B.E.; Rosquist, K.; Sviestins, E. (Stockholm Univ. (Sweden). Institutionen foer Teoretisk Fysik)
The behavior of null geodesics in a class of rotating space-time homogeneous cosmologies
United States
General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 13(11) p. 1093-1115; ISSN 0001-7701; Nov 1981
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
CAUSALITY; COORDINATES; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GEODESICS; GLOBAL ANALYSIS; MATTER; ROTATION; SHEAR; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS

The null geodesics are investigated in a class of open space-time homogeneous cosmological models with rotating sheared matter (Ozsvath class III). Goedel's model is a special case. A stationary polar coordinate system is employed in which matter rotates rigidly. The geodesic equations are solved. Caustics and global rotation are discussed. (author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Maiti, S.R. (Department of Physics, Presidency College, Calcutta-700073, India)
Fluid with heat flux in a conformally flat space-time
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 25(10) p. 2518-2520; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 May 1982
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; HEAT FLUX; MINKOWSKI SPACE; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SPACE-TIME; TENSORS; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; SPACE

This paper presents a solution of Einstein's equation in a conformally flat and spherically symmetric space-time with perfect fluid and heat flux as sources when vorticity and shear vanish. With a certain choice of parameters the solution may represent an earlier stage of the Robertson-Walker model. Though acceleration remains, a singularity cannot be avoided in some cases. The horizon of the model cannot be definitely known, but for a particular case it can be assigned. Other behaviors of the solution are similar to those of the Robertson-Walker metric
January 1982

Note on the breakdown of causality in a Goedel-like universe
Brazil
Report
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

metadata.@content: Reboucas, M.J.
Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Fisicas, Rio de Janeiro
Time-dependent, Bianchi II, rotating universe
Brazil
Report
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; ROTATION; TIME DEPENDENCE; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

An exact cosmological solution of Einstein's equations which has time-dependent rotation is presented. The t-constant sections are of Bianchi type II. The source of this geometry is a fluid which has not been thermalized. (Author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Temchin, A.N.
On linear gravitational waves
O linejnykh gravitatsionnykh volnakh
Russian
USSR
Izvestiya Vysshikh Uchebnykh Zavedenij, Fizika; v. 25(2) p. 98-101; ISSN 0021-3411; Feb 1982; For English translation see the journal Soviet Physics Journal (USA).
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; METRICS; P INVARIANCE; POLARIZATION; WAVE PROPAGATION
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES

Equations of a weak gravitational field are studied without usual simplificatttions. The aention is paid to the difference of gravitational waves from electromagnetic. It is shown that the weak gravitational waves, along with the polarization possess the orientation. Two P symmetrical sources radiate waves of opposite orientations; this suggests the possibility of unusuat interference effects
January 1982

metadata.@content: Breitenlohner, P.; Freedman, D.Z. (Massachusetts Inst. of Tech., Cambridge (USA). Dept. of Mathematics)
Positive energy in anti-de Sitter backgrounds and gauged extended supergravity
Netherlands
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUCTUATIONS; FUNCTIONALS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; METRICS; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SCALAR FIELDS; SUPERGRAVITY; VACUUM STATES

The energy functional of a field theory with anti-de Sitter background geometry can be positive for scalar potentials which are unbounded below and for vacua corresponding to critical points which are maxima or saddle points. (orig.)

metadata.@content: Marathe, K.B. (Brooklyn Coll., NY (USA). Dept. of Mathematics)
The mean curvature of gravitational fields
Netherlands
Physica A; v. 114(1-3) p. 143-145; ISSN 0378-4371; Aug 1982; 10. International colloquium on group theoretical methods in physics; Canterbury (UK); 31 Aug - 4 Sep 1981
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; DIFFERENTIAL TOPOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; METRICS; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; MATHEMATICS; SPACE; TOPOLOGY

The mean curvature of a gravitational field is defined as a generalization of the average curvature in a given direction by using the gravitational sectional curvature function on non-degenerate tangent 2-planes to the space-time manifold. We find that the mean curvature of a gravitational field is independent of direction as determined by a unit vector. The converse of this result provides a new characterization of spaces admitting gravitational fields. We also define the average curvature (or bending) of a non-degenerate k-plane in a gravitational field and shwo that it is independent of the choice of non-degenerated k-plane. (orig.)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Stewart, B.W. (Cincinnati Univ., OH (USA). Dept. of Physics)
A generalisation of the Buchdahl transformation and perfect fluid solutions
United Kingdom
Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 15(6) p. 1799-1805; ISSN 0305-4470; Jun 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; CANONICAL TRANSFORMATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUIDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; SYMMETRY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

Perfect fluid solutions in general relativity are examined. The pressure isotropy relation possesses a discrete symmetry in the derivatives of the metric functions. It is shown that a generalisation of Buchdahl's original transformation (Aust. J. Phys.; 9: 13 (1956)) allows new physically reasonable solutions to be obtained from known solutions. An example is given. Previously noticed first by Buchdahl, and later by Glass and Goldman (J. Math. Phys.; 19: 856 (1978)), this symmetry was thought to lead only to unphysical solutions. (author)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Spyrou, N. (Thessaloniki Univ. (Greece). Dept. of Astronomy)
Reversible transformations of shapes and sizes of uncharged ergospheres
United Kingdom
Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 15(6) p. 1979-1986; ISSN 0305-4470; Jun 1982
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ANGULAR MOMENTUM; BLACK HOLES; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; CANONICAL TRANSFORMATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; KERR FIELD; KERR METRIC
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS

The shape and size of a Kerr ergosphere and their reversible transformations are studied systematically. It is proved that due to the ergosphere's total angular momentum, a bulge always forms on its outer boundary either on the axis of rotational symmetry or off it. During the reversible increase of the angular momentum, because of the injection of particles into the ergosphere, the bulge can either approach the symmetry plane or recede from it, while its angular separation from the positive rotation axis increases continuously, approaching the value of 300 for the extreme Kerr ergosphere. The reversible changes of the ergosphere's linear dimensions parallel to the rotation axis and perpendicular to it are studied and the corresponding ranges of their permitted values are specified. (author)
January 1982

        <descriptor type="valid" key="00410" assignment="indexer">angular momentum</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="01114" assignment="indexer">black holes</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="01238" assignment="indexer">boundary conditions</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="01532" assignment="indexer">canonical transformations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11877" assignment="indexer">kerr field</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="13598" assignment="indexer">kerr metric</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11998" assignment="upposted">gravitational fields</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="upposted">metrics</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">The shape and size of a Kerr ergosphere and their reversible transformations are studied systematically. It is proved that due to the ergosphere's total angular momentum, a bulge always forms on its outer boundary either on the axis of rotational symmetry or off it. During the reversible increase of the angular momentum, because of the injection of particles into the ergosphere, the bulge can either approach the symmetry plane or recede from it, while its angular separation from the positive rotation axis increases continuously, approaching the value of 30<sup>0</sup> for the extreme Kerr ergosphere. The reversible changes of the ergosphere's linear dimensions parallel to the rotation axis and perpendicular to it are studied and the corresponding ranges of their permitted values are specified. (author)</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>
    <administratives>
      <input-center type="subj" key="GB">United Kingdom</input-center>
      <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights>
    </administratives>
  </record>
</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: Mielke, E.W. (International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)); Scherzer, R. (Kiel Univ. (Germany, F.R.). Inst. fuer Reine und Angewandte Kernphysik)
International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)
Geon-type solutions of the non-linear Heisenberg-Klein-Gordon equation
International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; GLUONS; KLEIN-GORDON EQUATION; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SCALAR FIELDS; SOLITONS; SPINORS

DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; PARTICLE MODELS; POSTULATED PARTICLES; QUASI PARTICLES; WAVE EQUATIONS

As a model for a ''unitary'' field theory of extended particles we consider the non-linear Klein-Gordon equation - associated with a ''squared'' Heisenberg-Pauli-Weyl non-linear spinor equation - coupled to strong gravity. Using a stationary spherical ansatz for the complex scalar field as well as for the background metric generated via Einstein's field equation, we are able to study the effects of the scalar self-interaction as well as of the classical tensor forces. By numerical integration we obtain a continuous spectrum of localized, gravitational solitons resembling the geons previously constructed for the Einstein-Maxwell system by Wheeler. A self-generated curvature potential originating from the curved background partially confines the Schroedinger type wave functions within the ''scalar geon''. For zero angular momentum states and normalized scalar charge the spectrum for the total gravitational energy of these solitons exhibits a branching with respect to the number of nodes appearing in the radial part of the scalar field. Preliminary studies for higher values of the corresponding ''principal quantum number'' reveal that a kind of fine splitting of the energy levels occurs, which may indicate a rich, particle-like structure of these ''quantized geons''. (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Choquet-Bruhat, Y. (Paris-6 Univ., 75 (France))
Recent results on the Cauchy problem for gravitation and Yang-Mills fields
Proceedings of the second Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands

Ruffini, R. (ed.) (Rome Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica); International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy); 752 p; ISBN 0 444 86357 5; 1982; p. 167-178; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 2. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Trieste (Italy); 5 - 11 Jul 1979
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)

BANACH SPACE; BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS; CAUCHY PROBLEM; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; METRICS; RIEMANN SPACE; TENSORS; VECTOR FIELDS; YANG-MILLS THEORY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE

The author gives a brief account of some progresses which have been made recently on the Cauchy problem in General Relativity, for pure gravitation or gravitation coupled with other fields. The two aspects of this problem are examined: the evolution of initial data; the solution of the constraint equations for the initial data. (Auth.)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Sato, H. (Kyoto Univ. (Japan). Research Inst. for Fundamental Physics)
Metric solution of a spinning mass
Proceedings of the second Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands

Ruffini, R. (ed.) (Rome Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica); International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy); 752 p; ISBN 0 444 86357 5; 1982; p. 353-370; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 2. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Trieste (Italy); 5 - 11 Jul 1979; 93 refs.
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; BIBLIOGRAPHIES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEODESICS; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; KERR METRIC; REVIEWS; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SPACE-TIME
DOCUMENT TYPES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

Studies on a particular class of asymptotically flat and stationary metric solutions called the Kerr-Tomimatsu-Sato class are reviewed about its derivation and properties. For a further study, an almost complete list of the papers worked on the Tomimatsu-Sato metrics is given. (Auth.)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Kihara, Masahiro; Nariai, Hidekazu.
Hiroshima Univ., Takehara (Japan). Research Inst. for Theoretical Physics
A cosmological version of flatness conditions in general relativity
Japan
Report
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

In terms of our cosmological extention of Arnowitt, Deser and Misner's canonical formalism to the Einstein equations, Arnowitt and Deser's flatness conditions in general relativity are reformulated on the simplifying assumption that the cosmological vacuum is represented by the de Sitter universe. (author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Frenkel, A.; Brecher, K. (Department of Astronomy, Boston University, Boston, Massachusetts 02215)
Horizon-free universe
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 26(2) p. 368-372; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Jul 1982
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; RICCI TENSOR; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; TENSORS

We have studied a theory of gravity, consistent with all astronomical observations, which is an extension of general relativity generated by a gravitational field Lagrangian proportional to R+AR2 (where R is the scalar curvature and A is a new dimensional constant). We find cosmological solutions without a particle horizon for any value of A, compatible with cosmological observations if A is negative and small enough. It is pointed out that while alleviating the problem of the large-scale physical uniformity of the universe, the theory may also alleviate the problem of the development of smaller-scale structures from an initially isotropic state, and possibly the problem of ''hidden mass.''
January 1982

metadata.@content: Canuto, V.M. (National Aeronautics and Space Administration, New York (USA). Goddard Inst. for Space Studies)
Scale covariant cosmology and astrophysical applications
Proceedings of the second Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands

Ruffini, R. (ed.) (Rome Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica); International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy); 567 p; ISBN 0 444 86357 5; 1982; p. 729-784; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 2. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Trieste (Italy); 5 - 11 Jul 1979
Book
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

ATOMIC CLOCKS; COMPILED DATA; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; EXPANSION; FUNDAMENTAL CONSTANTS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; HUBBLE EFFECT; HYPOTHESIS; METRICS; QUASARS; RADIO GALAXIES; RED SHIFT; SCALE INVARIANCE; SEYFERT GALAXIES; THEORETICAL DATA; THERMODYNAMICS; TIME MEASUREMENT; UNIVERSE; VARIATIONS
COSMIC RADIO SOURCES; DATA; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; GALAXIES; INFORMATION; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NUMERICAL DATA

The success of the Weinberg-Salam theory has clearly indicated that at least two forces of nature, electromagnetic and weak, can be unified in a single scheme. While there are well-founded hopes that even strong interactions will soon be brought into a unified scheme, there has been no tangible success towards the inclusion of gravity. The author therefore adopts a different point of view, i.e., a phenomenological approach towards the unification problem. The results of an extensive analysis are presented that show that a large body of data from astronomy, astrophysics, cosmology, geophysics and paleontology, are compatible with a scheme in which all the forces were of the same strength in the early phases of the Big Bang. (Auth.)
January 1982

Thesis/Dissertation
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
BOUNDARY VALUE PROBLEMS; CAUCHY PROBLEM; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; SPACE-TIME; VACUUM STATES
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS

The initial value problems in general relativity are considered from a geometrical standpoint with especial reference to the development of a covariant 2+2 formalism in which space-time is foliated by space-like 2-surfaces under the headings; the Cauchy problem in general relativity, the covariant 3+1 formulation of the Cauchy problem, characteristic and mixed initial value problems, on locally imbedding a family of null hypersurfaces, the 2+2 formalism, the 2+2 formulation of the Cauchy problem, the 2+2 formulation of the characteristic and mixed initial value problems, and a covariant Lagrangian 2+2 formulation. (U.K.)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Lugo, G.G.
California Univ., Berkeley (USA)
Structure of twistor and H-spaces
United States
1979; 74 p; ;  University Microfilms Order No. 80-14,783; Thesis (Ph. D.).
Thesis/Dissertation
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEODESICS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; SPACE-TIME; SPINORS; TWISTOR THEORY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; SPACE

In chapter one, we review briefly the spinor and twistor formalisms in general relativity. Following some suggestions of A.H. Taub, we show that the local twistor structure of a general curved space-time is closely related to the conformal structure used by B.G. Schmidt to define conformal infinity. In particular, we prove that the normal Cartan connection of the conformal bundle coincides with the connection which gives the covariant derivative of local twistors. In chapter two, we use the results of E.T. Newman and J. Plebanski to construct some explicit self-dual metrics. These solutions are of interest because they are good candidates for what we would like to call asymptotically flat H-spaces. Furthermore, by a closer look at these metrics, we may gain more insight into the behavior of twistor spaces near the boundary. In chapter three, we study the geometric structure of twistor spaces associated with asymptotically flat space-times. We show that the space of asymptotic projective twistors, PT+, is an Einstein Kaehler manifold of constant holomorphic sectional curvature. We also give a brief description of the twistor space construction of the metrics in chapter two. In chapter four, we apply the Chern-Moser theory of the pseudoconformal geometry of real hypersurfaces in complex manifolds to study the structure of the boundary PN of PT+. Using some ideas due to S. Webster, we show that the Chern-Moser curvature invariants of PN coincide with the Kaehler curvature invariants of PT+. From the results of chapter three, we deduce that the pseudoconformal geodesics (chains) of the boundary are nicely behaved
s of PN coincide with the Kaehler curvature invariants of PT+. From the results of chapter three, we deduce that the pseudoconformal geodesics (chains) of the boundary are nicely behaved
January 1979

Scale-covariant gravitation and primordial nucleosynthesis
United States
Astrophysical Journal; v. 257(2) p. 450-455; ISSN 0004-637X; 15 Jun 1982
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
CHEMICAL COMPOSITION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS OF STATE; EXPANSION; GRAVITATION; HELIUM 4; NUCLEOSYNTHESIS; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; EVEN-EVEN NUCLEI; FIELD EQUATIONS; HELIUM ISOTOPES; ISOTOPES; LIGHT NUCLEI; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; NUCLEI; STABLE ISOTOPES

By considering the modification in conservation laws when the gravitational constant G is allowed by via a scale-invariant formalism, we place consistent limits on G/G. If Gproportionalt/sup epsilon-c/, then our ''best'' model has Vertical Barepsilon-cVertical Bar< or approx. =3 x 10-3 and Vertical BarG/GVertical Bar/sub now/approx.Vertical Barepsilont-1/sub now/Vertical Bar< or approx. =1.7 x 10-13 yr-1. These values are comparable to, but approximately a factor of 2 stronger than, limits found in naive models where the conservation laws are not taken into account
January 1982

metadata.@content: Nakamura, Takashi; Sato, Humitaka (Kyoto Univ. (Japan). Research Inst. for Fundamental Physics)
General relativistic collapse of rotating supermassive stars
Japan
Progress of Theoretical Physics (Kyoto); v. 66(6) p. 2038-2051; ISSN 0033-068X; Dec 1981
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

ANGULAR MOMENTUM; BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GALACTIC EVOLUTION; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; METRICS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; ROTATION; SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION; STAR EVOLUTION; SUPERMASSIVE STARS
DISTRIBUTION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; STARS

Numerical calculations have been done for the formation process of axisymmetric, rotating supermassive black holes. Polytropic distribution with N = 3 is used as the initial density distribution. Calculated models are characterized by the total angular momentum (J) and the rotation law. The two types of the initial rotation law are examined. As the effect of rotation is the strongest at the center for the differential rotation law case, the matter distribution becomes disk-like. In this case, if q = (J/M2) <= 0.92 an apparent horizon is formed. If q >= 0.92, the disk-like matter expands toward the lateral direction. For the almost rigidly rotating case, the oblate shape core is always formed because the effect of rotation at the center is not so strong as the former case. In this case if q <= 1.05 an apparent horizon is formed. For large q, for example q = 1.46, the central core bounces and a jet which expands mainly along the rotational axis appears. For the collapse of 109 M sub(solar mass) star, the kinetic energy of the jet becomes 3.6 x 1060 ergs, which is comparable to the total energy stored in the radio lobes of the extragalactic double radio sources. (author)
January 1981

ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (A2100); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COMPOSITE MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUIDS; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; METRICS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; PARTICLE INTERACTIONS; SPHERES; STRONG INTERACTIONS
BASIC INTERACTIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INTERACTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PARTICLE MODELS; SPACE

We show that if the late stages in the nakedly singular collapse of a radiating fluid sphere are treated within the framework of a composite (''bootstrap'') model of strongly interacting particles then the end state need only be instantaneously singular. This is in contrast to the elementary-particle description which does not allow a smooth continuation of the external field onto Minkowski space
January 1982

metadata.@content: D'Auria, R.; Fre, P.; Regge, T. (Turin Univ. (Italy))
Graded-Lie-algebra cohomology and supergravity
Italy
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GEOMETRY; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL MANIFOLDS; REVIEWS; SPACE-TIME; SUPERGRAVITY
DOCUMENT TYPES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS; SYMMETRY GROUPS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

Detailed explanations of the cohomology invoked in the group-manifold approach to supergravity is given. The Chevalley cohomology theory of Lie algebras is extended to graded Lie algebras. The scheme of geometrical theories is enlarged so to include cosmological terms and higher powers of the curvature. (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Fagundes, H.V. (Instituto de Fisica Teorica, Sao Paulo (Brazil))
A cosmological model with compact space sections and low mass density
Netherlands
Letters in Mathematical Physics; v. 6(6) p. 417-428; ISSN 0377-9017; Nov 1982; CODEN: LMPHD.
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DENSITY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; METRICS; QUASARS; SPACE-TIME
COSMIC RADIO SOURCES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES

A general relativistic cosmological model is presented which has closed space sections and mass density below a critical density similar to that of Friedmann's models. The model may predict double images of cosmic sources: a hint is made at a qualitative application to quasar astronomy. (orig.)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Tevikian, R.V.
Erevanskij Fizicheskij Inst. (USSR)
Lorentz-invariance and vacuum fields
USSR
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
BOSONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FERMIONS; LORENTZ INVARIANCE; MAGNETIC MONOPOLES; POINCARE GROUPS; VACUUM POLARIZATION
ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; MONOPOLES; POSTULATED PARTICLES; SYMMETRY GROUPS

It is shown that for the complete description of the particle fields at E  infinity it is necessary to introduce bose- and fermi-vacuum fields. It is proved that in the Einstein equations it is necessary to ihtroduce a cosmological term proportional to the square of the bose-vacuum field strength
January 1981

metadata.@content: Martellini, M. (Cambridge Univ., England)
Observable effects of foam-like structure of space-time. III
United States
Hadronic Journal; v. 3(3) p. 1018-1038; ISSN 0162-5519; Apr 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
DEEP INELASTIC SCATTERING; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SCALE INVARIANCE; SPACE-TIME; UNIFIED GAUGE MODELS

EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INELASTIC SCATTERING; INTERACTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LEPTON-BARYON INTERACTIONS; LEPTON-HADRON INTERACTIONS; LEPTON-NUCLEON INTERACTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE INTERACTIONS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; SCATTERING

In this paper we show that the contribution to the Bjorken scaling violation, which is due to the gravitational field, disappears at very short distances because of the foam-like structure of the space-time
January 1980
