metadata.@content: Higuchi, A. (Physics Department, Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut 06511 and Department of Physics, University of Wisconsin--Milwaukee, Milwaukee, Wisconsin 53201)
Symmetric tensor spherical harmonics on the N-sphere and their application to the de Sitter group SO(N,1)
United States
J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(7) p. 1553-1566; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Jul 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

COSMOLOGY; DE SITTER GROUP; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GROUP THEORY; QUANTUM OPERATORS; RECURSION RELATIONS; SO GROUPS; SPACE-TIME; SPHERICAL HARMONICS; SYMMETRY; TENSORS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL OPERATORS; MATHEMATICS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

The symmetric tensor spherical harmonics (STSH's) on the N-sphere (S/sup N/), which are defined as the totally symmetric, traceless, and divergence-free tensor eigenfunctions of the Laplace--Beltrami (LB) operator on S/sup N/, are studied. Specifically, their construction is shown recursively starting from the lower-dimensional ones. The symmetric traceless tensors induced by STSH's are introduced. These play a crucial role in the recursive construction of STSH's. The normalization factors for STSH's are determined by using their transformation properties under SO(N+1). Then the symmetric, traceless, and divergence-free tensor eigenfunctions of the LB operator in the N-dimensional de Sitter space-time which are obtained by the analytic continuation of the STSH's on S/sup N/ are studied. Specifically, the allowed eigenvalues of the LB operator under the restriction of unitarity are determined. Our analysis gives a group-theoretical explanation of the forbidden mass range observed earlier for the spin-2 field theory in de Sitter space-time
January 1987

metadata.@content: Weber, E. (Universite Catholique de Louvain, Institut de Physique Theorique, B-1348 Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium and Universite du Burundi, B. P. 2700 Bujumbura, Burundi)
Global qualitative study of Bianchi universes in the presence of a cosmological constant
United States
J. Math. Phys. (N.Y.); v. 28(7) p. 1658-1666; ISSN 0022-2488; CODEN JMAPA; Jul 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; ORGANIZING; RELICT RADIATION; SINGULARITY; UNIVERSE
ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MICROWAVE RADIATION; RADIATIONS; SPACE

A particular class of nonempty spatially homogeneous orthogonal cosmologies of the Bianchi classification is considered in the presence of a nonzero cosmological constant , i.e., cosmologies that can be transformed into a three-dimensional autonomous dynamical system: these are the axisymmetric type II, the pseudoaxisymmetric type VI0, and the (n/sup //sub / = 0) types V, VI/sub h/ (including III = VI/sub -/1). A qualitative method to investigate such dynamical systems as a whole is presented. The qualitative study yields for every type a set of solutions of nonzero measure and another one of zero measure becoming isotropic in an infinite cosmological time when >0
January 1987

metadata.@content: Logunov, A.A. (Moskovskij Gosudarstvennyj Univ. (USSR))
Relativistic theory of gravitation and new representations of space-time
Relyativistskaya teoriya gravitatsii i novye predstavleniya o prostranstve-vremeni
Russian
USSR

Vestnik Moskovskogo Universiteta, Seriya 3. Fizika, Astronomiya; v. 27(6) p. 3-15; ISSN 0579-9392; CODEN VMUFA; Nov-Dec 1986; For English translation see the journal Moscow University Physics Bulletin (USA).
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

CONSERVATION LAWS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LORENTZ TRANSFORMATIONS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; POINCARE GROUPS; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE; SYMMETRY GROUPS; TENSORS

General relativity theory main insurmountable difficulties, leading to refusal from GRT are briefly summarized; relativistic theory of gravity (RTG) and its principles are presented. RTG is free from these difficulties and explains the whole set of gravitation observation and experimental data, predicting new representations about the Universe development and gravitational collapse RTG is a further development of Poincare, Minkowski, Einstein and Hilbert ideas. It strikes against dogmatism which is characteristic of RTG
January 1986

metadata.@content: Nariai, Hidekazu.
Hiroshima Univ., Takehara (Japan). Research Inst. for Theoretical Physics
On some peculiar space-times with spherical symmetry
Japan
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1140)
COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; METRICS; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

As an extension of my old papers (1950 - 1) on a peculiar solution of the vacuum Einstein equations with the cosmological constant, i.e., R = g, I reproduce the content of my Research Note (dated on October 6th, 1960) on some peculiar space-times with spherical symmetry, because it includes not only the Kantowski and Sach's solution of Einstein's equations for a dust fluid without , but also the one for a dust fluid with 0, in addition to the case where R = g (in similar to Nariai's solution). (author)
January 1986

metadata.@content: Accioly, A.J. (Sao Paulo Univ. (Brazil). Inst. de Fisica); Goncalves, A.T. (Rio de Janeiro Univ. (Brazil). Inst. de Fisica)
Sao Paulo Univ. (Brazil). Inst. de Fisica
Homogeneous space-time of Goedel type in higher-derivate gravity
Brazil
Oct 1986; 13 p; IFUSP-P--604
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
ACTION INTEGRAL; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; METRICS; ROTATION; SPACE-TIME; UNIVERSE; VORTICES
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTEGRALS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

A general theorem concerning any Goedel-type solution of higher-derivative gravity field equations, which may be produced by any reasonable physical source with a constant energy-momentum tensor, is analysed. The resulting class of metrics dependes on two parameters, one of which is related to the vorticity. A general class of solutions of Goedel-type space-time-homogeneous universes in the context of the higher-derivative theory is exhibited. This is the most general higher-derivative solution of such type of metric and includes all known solutions of Einstei's equations related to these geometries as a special case. A number of completely causal rotating models is also obtained. Some of them present the interesting feature of having no analogous in the framework of general relativity. (Author)
January 1986

A general class of solutions of Goedel-type space-time-homogeneous universes in the context of the higher-derivative theory is exhibited. A number of completely causal rotating models is also obtained. Some of them present the interesting feature of having no analogous in the framework of general relativity. (Author)</abstract>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="pt">Um teorema geral relacionado a qualquer solucao do tipo Goedel de equacoes de campo de gravitacao de derivadas mais altas, que podem ser produzidas por qualquer fonte fisica razoavel com um tensor de energia-momento constante, e analizado. A classe de metricas resultantes depende sobre dois parametros, um dos quais e relacionado a vorticidade. Uma classe geral de solucoes de universos de espaco-tempo homogeneo do tipo Goedel, no contexto da teoria de derivadas mais altas, e exibida. Essa e a solucao de derivadas mais altas mais geral desse tipo de metrica e inclui todas as solucoes conhecidas das equacoes de Einstein relacionadas a esses geometrias como um caso especial. Um numero de modelos de rotacao completamente causal e tambem obtido. Alguns deles apresentam a interessante caracteristica de nao ter nenhum analogo no contexto da relatividade geral. metadata.@content: Ehlers, J. (Max-Planck-Institut fuer Physik und Astrophysik, Garching (Germany, F.R.). Inst. fuer Astrophysik); Prasanna, A.R. (Physical Research Lab., Ahmedabad (India)); Breuer, R.A. (GEO Magazine, Hamburg (Germany, F.R.))
Propagation of gravitational waves through pressureless matter
United Kingdom
Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 4(2) p. 253-264; ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRD; 1 Mar 1987
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
AMPLITUDES; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; DENSITY; DISPERSION RELATIONS; DUSTS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GEODESICS; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; SPACE-TIME; VARIATIONS; VELOCITY; WAVE PROPAGATION; WKB APPROXIMATION
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES

The propagation of small-amplitude gravitational waves through pressureless matter ('dust') is investigated. After establishing the local linearisation stability of Einstein's equation for dust about any of its solutions, the Wentzel-Kramers-Brillouin (WKB) method is used to study the locally plane, linearised perturbations of an arbitrary background dust spacetime asymptotically for small wavelengths. The dispersion relation exhibits two modes. One is simply degenerate and represents gravitational waves, whereas the other is doubly degenerate and describes density and vorticity perturbations. The waves are shown to propagate along the null geodesics of the background; in leading WKB order their amplitudes behave as in vacuo. The rays associated with the matter mode are the worldlines of the background dust. In leading order the perturbations of density and 4-velocity vanish for both modes. (author)
January 1987

The dispersion relation exhibits two modes. One is simply degenerate and represents gravitational waves, whereas the other is doubly degenerate and describes density and vorticity perturbations. The waves are shown to propagate along the null geodesics of the background; in leading WKB order their amplitudes behave as in vacuo. The rays associated with the matter mode are the worldlines of the background dust. In leading order the perturbations of density and 4-velocity vanish for both modes. (author)</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>
    <administratives>
      <input-center type="subj" key="GB">United Kingdom</input-center>
      <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights>
    </administratives>
  </record>
</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: Starobinsky, A.A. (AN SSSR, Moscow. Inst. Teoreticheskoj Fiziki); Schmidt, H.-J. (Akademie der Wissenschaften der DDR, Potsdam. Zentralinstitut fuer Astrophysik)
On a general vacuum solution of fourth-order gravity
United Kingdom
Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 4(3) p. 695-702; ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRD; 1 May 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGY; DE SITTER GROUP; DEGREES OF FREEDOM; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; INFLATIONARY UNIVERSE; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

The authors generalise the result derived for the Einstein theory with the cosmological term (the general asymptotic solution containing four arbitrary functions of three coordinates) to fourth-order gravity. For scale-invariant fourth-order gravity the expanding generalised de Sitter solution is found to be an attractor, i.e. for t  infinity an open neighbourhood of solutions approach this one. For (R + R2) gravity, one obtains an intermediate de Sitter stage with a high probability that is followed by a power-law Friedman stage. Finally, it is argued that the inclusion of ordinary inhomogeneously distributed matter does not alter these results. (author)
January 1987

metadata.@content: Melnikov, V.N.; Stanukovich, K.P. (USSR State Committee for Standards, Leninsky Prospekt 9, Moscow 117049)
Model systems of fields in the theory of gravitation and the problems of cosmology
Gravitational radiation and relativity
United States
Weber, J.; Karade, T.M; p. 418-430; ISBN 9971-978-88-1; 1986; p. 418-430; World Scientific Pub. Co; Teaneck, NJ (USA)
Book

Exact solutions of classical and quantum fields in GR and quantum cosmology are obtained and applied to the solution of fundamental problems of cosmology. The problem of variations of fundamental constants and some relations among basic parameters of fundamental interactions are also discussed
January 1986

metadata.@content: Matsuo, N. (Osaka Univ., Toyonaka (Japan). Dept. of Physics)
Superstring thermodynamics and its application to cosmology
Germany
Zeitschrift fuer Physik. C, Particles and Fields; v. 36(2) p. 289-304; ISSN 0170-9739; CODEN ZPCFD; Sep 1987
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1130)
COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FREE ENERGY; PARTITION FUNCTIONS; STRING MODELS; SUPERSYMMETRY; THERMODYNAMICS; UNIVERSE
ENERGY; EQUATIONS; EXTENDED PARTICLE MODEL; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PARTICLE MODELS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; SYMMETRY; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES

The thermodynamics of superstring theories (SST-I, SST-II) and heterotic string theory and its application to the cosmology are studied. The free energy of superstring gas is calculated in the one-loop approximation and the stability of the extra torus dimensions is discussed. Assuming that the Einstein equation dictates the evolution of the universe, we show that matter dominated universe filled with massive particles would never be realized at the beginning of the universe, contrary to the naive expectation in the superstring cosmology. (orig.)
January 1987

metadata.@content: Accioly, A.J. (5529364BR)
Instituto de Fisica Teorica, Sao Paulo, SP (Brazil)
A classical approach to higher-derivative gravity
Brazil
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION
EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

Two classical routes towards higher-derivative gravity theory are described. The first one is a geometrical route, starting from first principles. The second route is a formal one, and is based on a recent theorem by Castagnino et.al. [J. Math. Phys. 28 (1987) 1854]. A cosmological solution of the higher-derivative field equations is exhibited which in a classical framework singles out this gravitation theory. (author)
January 1988

metadata.@content: Barreto, W.; Nunez, L.A.
International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)
Radiating spheres in general relativity with a mixed transport energy flow
International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; DIFFUSION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; HYDRODYNAMICS; RADIATION STREAMING; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FLUID MECHANICS; MECHANICS; METRICS; TENSORS

A seminumeric method by Herrera, Jimenez and Ruggeri is extended to handle the evolution of general relativistic spheres where diffusion and free streaming radiation processes coexist. It is shown when mixed-mode radiation is present a very different hydrodynamic picture emerges from the models previously considered in both radiation limits. Characteristic times for free streaming, hydrodynamics and diffusion processes are considered comparable. Hydrodynamics and radiation are strongly coupled and the particular equation of state of the model emerges as a very important element in the dynamic of the matter distribution. (author). 16 refs, 5 figs
January 1989

<html><head><META http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head><body><inisrecord>
  <action trn="XA9025929" type="add" />
  <record role="document" source-system="fibre" trn="XA9025929" type="report" rn="21032746">
    <publication>
      <titles>
        <title type="primary" xml:lang="en">Radiating spheres in general relativity with a mixed transport energy flow</title>
      </titles>
      <date value="1989-10-" sici-chronology="198910">Oct 1989</date>
      <physical-description>27 p.</physical-description>
      <country key="XA">International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)</country>
      <creators and-others="no">
        <creator type="personal">Barreto, W.</creator>
        <creator type="personal">Nunez, L.A.</creator>
        <creator type="corporate">International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)</creator>
      </creators>
      <identifiers>
        <identifier type="report-number">IC--89/339</identifier>
      </identifiers>
      <availability inis="yes">
        <contact>Available from INIS: http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:21032746</contact>
        <copies>
          <copy href="http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:21032746">http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:21032746</copy>
        </copies>
      </availability>
    </publication>
    <classification>
      <categories>
        <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1120" />
      </categories>
      <descriptors>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="00389" assignment="indexer">analytical solution</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02647" assignment="indexer">diffusion</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="21731" assignment="indexer">energy-momentum tensor</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03915" assignment="indexer">general relativity theory</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="04547" assignment="indexer">hydrodynamics</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08187" assignment="indexer">radiation streaming</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08872" assignment="indexer">schwarzschild metric</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03558" assignment="upposted">fluid mechanics</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="05945" assignment="upposted">mechanics</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="upposted">metrics</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09910" assignment="upposted">tensors</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">A seminumeric method by Herrera, Jimenez and Ruggeri is extended to handle the evolution of general relativistic spheres where diffusion and free streaming radiation processes coexist. It is shown when mixed-mode radiation is present a very different hydrodynamic picture emerges from the models previously considered in both radiation limits. Characteristic times for free streaming, hydrodynamics and diffusion processes are considered comparable. Hydrodynamics and radiation are strongly coupled and the particular equation of state of the model emerges as a very important element in the dynamic of the matter distribution. (author). 16 refs, 5 figs</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>
    <administratives>
      <input-center type="subj" key="XA">International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)</input-center>
      <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights>
    </administratives>
  </record>
</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: Aliev, V.N.; Leznov, A.N.
Gosudarstvennyj Komitet po Ispol'zovaniyu Atomnoj Ehnergii SSSR, Serpukhov (USSR). Inst. Fiziki Vysokikh Ehnergij
Exact solutions of the vacuum Einstein's equations allowing for two noncommuting Killing vectors
USSR
1990; 13 p; IHEP-OTF--90-50; (IFVE-OTF--90-50); Submitted to J. Math. Phys.
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; METRICS; RICCI TENSOR; TWO-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; VECTORS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; TENSORS

Einstein's equations are written in the form of covariant gauge theory in two-dimensional space with binomial solvable gauge group, with respect to two noncommutative of Killing vectors. The theory is exact integrable in one-dimensional case and series of partial exact solutions are constructed in two-dimensional. 5 refs
January 1990

metadata.@content: Rago, H.
International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)
Anisotropic spheres in general relativity
International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; ANISOTROPY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

A prescription originally conceived for perfect fluids is extended to the case of anisotropic pressures. The method is used to obtain exact analytical solutions of the Einstein equations for spherically symmetric selfgravitating distribution of anisotropic matter. The solutions are matched to the Schwarzschild exterior metric. (author). 15 refs
January 1991

metadata.@content: Alvarado, R.; Rybakov, Yu.P.; Shikin, G.N. (Universitet Druzhby Narodov, Moscow (Russian Federation)); Saha, B. (Joint Inst. for Nuclear Research, Dubna (Russian Federation). Lab. of Theoretical Physics)
Joint Inst. for Nuclear Research, Dubna (Russian Federation). Lab. of Theoretical Physics
Exact self-consistent solutions to the interacting spinor and scalar field equations in Bianchi type-I space-time
English
Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (JINR)
1995; 10 p; JINR-E--2-95-16; Submitted to Communications in Theoretical Physics.
Report
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (G2110)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; METRICS; SCALAR FIELDS; SELF-CONSISTENT FIELD; SPACE-TIME; SPINORS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; TENSORS

Self-consistent solutions to the system of spinor and scalar field equations in General Relativity are studied for the case of Bianchi type-I space-time. The absence of initial singularity should be emphasized for some types of solutions and also the isotropic mode of space-time expansion in some special cases. 3 refs
January 1995

metadata.@content: Dirar, M. (International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)); El-Tahir, A.; Shaddad, M.H. (Khartoum Univ., Khartoum (Sudan). Dept. of Physics)
International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)
A new derivation of the generalized field equation with a source term
English
International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Report
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (G2210)
ACTION INTEGRAL; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; INTERACTION RANGE; LAGRANGIAN FIELD THEORY; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; NUCLEAR FORCES; PULSARS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES
COSMIC RADIO SOURCES; DISTANCE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; INTEGRALS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY

A simple derivation of the generalized field equation with a source term is presented by restricting ourselves to a locally inertial frame. It reduces to Einstein's field equation when the Lagrangian is linear. Assuming the metric to be Minkowskian, simple solutions for the scalar curvature show the existence of a short range field and the emission of gravitational waves by objects which have strong field. (author). 10 refs
January 1996

metadata.@content: Martins, M.R.; Silva, M.F.A. da (Universidade do Estado do Rio de Janeiro (UERJ), RJ (Brazil). Dept. de Fisica Teorica)
Sociedade Brasileira de Fisica (SBF), Sao Paulo, SP (Brazil)
Black hole from dark energy in 2+1 gravity
English
Brazil

2006; 6 p; 27. Brazilian national meeting on particle physics and fields; 27. Encontro nacional de fisica de particulas e campos; Aguas de Lindoia, SP (Brazil); 24-28 Sep 2006; INIS-BR--6097; ;  Also available from http://www.sbf1.sbfisica.org.br/eventos/enfpc/xxvii/sys/resumos/T0222-2.pdf; 5 refs.
Miscellaneous
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)
BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; EQUATIONS OF STATE; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; PRESSURE DEPENDENCE; SPACE-TIME; THREE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; TENSORS

In this paper we solve the Einsteins' field equations for a spherically symmetric anisotropic fluid, with kinematic self-similarity of the first kind, in spacetimes (2+1)-dimensional. Considering a null radial pressure we show that the fluid collapses forming a black hole in the end, even if it is constituted by phantom energy. (author)
January 2006
http://www.sbf1.sbfisica.org.br/eventos/enfpc/xxvii/sys/resumos/T0222-2.pdf

metadata.@content: Yi-Ping, Qin (Center for Astrophysics, Guangzhou University, Guangzhou 510006, China Physics Department, Guangxi University, Nanning 530004 (China)), E-mail: ypqin@126.com
A cosmological model with negative energy photons
English
China
Chinese Physics. B; v. 19(1); ISSN 1674-1056; Jan 2010; [5 p.]; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1674-1056/19/1/019803; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)
ASTROPHYSICS; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; PHOTONS; SUPERNOVAE; UNIVERSE
BINARY STARS; BOSONS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; ERUPTIVE VARIABLE STARS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; PHYSICS; STARS; VARIABLE STARS

According to recent investigations of states of quantum fields, we postulate that there exist negative energy photons in the universe. With this assumption, we find a solution of Einstein's equation without introducing the cosmological constant. A new and sizable type Ia supernovae sample is employed to perform a fit with our model and the conventional model. Both models can well account for the current type Ia supernovae observation and they are not distinguishable. With the new model, the cause of the accelerated expansion of the universe and the mechanism of the negative pressure existing in outer space can be explained in ordinary physical terms. (geophysics, astronomy and astrophysics)
January 2010

metadata.@content: El-Menoufi, Basem Mahmoud; Ett, Benjamin; Kastor, David; Traschen, Jennie (Department of Physics, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA 01003 (United States)), E-mail: bmahmoud@physics.umass.edu, E-mail: bett@physics.umass.edu, E-mail: kastor@physics.umass.edu, E-mail: traschen@physics.umass.edu
Sum rule for the ADM mass and tensions in planar AdS spacetimes
English
United Kingdom

Classical and Quantum Gravity; v. 30(20); ISSN 0264-9381; CODEN CQGRDG; 21 Oct 2013; [12 p.]; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0264-9381/30/20/205006; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (S71); PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; MASS; SCALING; SPACE-TIME; STRESSES; SUM RULES; SYMMETRY; VECTORS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; TENSORS

An asymptotically planar AdS spacetimes is characterized by its ADM mass and tensions. We define an additional ADM charge Q associated with the scaling Killing vector of AdS, show that Q is given by a certain sum over the ADM mass and tensions and that Q vanishes on solutions to the Einstein equation with  < 0. The sum rule for the mass and tensions thus established corresponds in an AdS/CFT context to the vanishing of the trace of the boundary stress tensor. We also show that an analogous sum rule holds for local planar sources of stressenergy in AdS. In a simple model consisting of a static, plane symmetric source we find that the perturbative stressenergy tensor must be tracefree. (paper)
January 2013

metadata.@content: Balakin, Alexander B.; Muharlyamov, Ruslan K.; Zayats, Alexei E. (Kazan Federal University, Department of General Relativity and Gravitation, Institute of Physics, Kazan (Russian Federation))
Electromagnetic waves in an axion-active relativistic plasma non-minimally coupled to gravity
English
Germany
European Physical Journal. C; v. 73(12); ISSN 1434-6044; Dec 2013; p. 1-19; ;  Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-013-2647-8
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (S71); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; COUPLING; DAMPING; DE SITTER SPACE; DISPERSION RELATIONS; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; METRICS; PHASE VELOCITY; RELATIVISTIC PLASMA; SCALAR FIELDS; SELF-CONSISTENT FIELD; WAVE PROPAGATION
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PLASMA; RADIATIONS; SPACE; VELOCITY

We consider cosmological applications of a new self-consistent system of equations, accounting for a non-minimal coupling of the gravitational, electromagnetic and pseudoscalar (axion) fields in a relativistic plasma. We focus on dispersion relations for electromagnetic perturbations in an initially isotropic ultrarelativistic plasma coupled to the gravitational and axion fields in the framework of isotropic homogeneous cosmological model of the de Sitter type. We classify the longitudinal and transversal electromagnetic modes in an axionically active plasma and distinguish between waves (damping, instable or running), and nonharmonic perturbations (damping or instable). We show that for the special choice of the guiding model parameters the transversal electromagnetic waves in the axionically active plasma, non-minimally coupled to gravity, can propagate with the phase velocity smaller than the speed of light in vacuum, thus displaying a possibility for a new type of resonant particle-wave interactions. (orig.)
January 2013

metadata.@content: Madriz Aguilar, Jose Edgar; Reyes, Luz M.; Moreno, Claudia (Universidad de Guadalajara (UdG), Departamento de Matematicas, Centro Universitario de Ciencias Exactas e ingenierias (CUCEI), Guadalajara, Jalisco (Mexico)); Bellini, Mauricio (Universidad Nacional de Mar del Plata (UNMdP), Departamento de Fisica, Facultad de Ciencias Exactas y Naturales, Funes 3350, C.P. 7600, Mar del Plata (Argentina); Consejo Nacional de Investigaciones Cientificas y Tecnicas (CONICET), Instituto de Investigaciones Fisicas de Mar del Plata (IFIMAR), Mar del Plata (Argentina))
Scalar fluctuations of the scalar metric during inflation from a non-perturbative 5D large-scale repulsive gravity model
English
Germany
European Physical Journal. C; v. 73(10); ISSN 1434-6044; Oct 2013; p. 1-8; ;  Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-013-2598-0
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; DE SITTER SPACE; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EXPANSION; FLUCTUATIONS; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; HUBBLE EFFECT; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; QUASI PARTICLES; SCALAR FIELDS; SCALE INVARIANCE; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SPACE-TIME; TOPOLOGICAL FOLIATION; TOPOLOGICAL MAPPING; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MAPPING; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; RELATIVITY THEORY; SPACE; TRANSFORMATIONS; VARIATIONS

We develop a non-perturbative formalism for scalar metric fluctuations from a 5D extended version of general relativity in vacuum. In this work we concentrate our efforts on calculations valid on large cosmological scales, which are dominant during the inflationary phase of the universe. The resulting metric in this limit is obtained after implementing a planar coordinate transformation on a 5D Ricci-flat metric solution. We calculate the spectrum of these fluctuations with an effective 4D Schwarzschild-de Sitter spacetime on cosmological scales, which is obtained after we make a static foliation on the non-compact extra coordinate. Our results show how the squared metric fluctuations of the primordial universe become scale invariant with the inflationary expansion. (orig.)
January 2013

        <descriptor type="valid" key="05907" assignment="upposted">mathematical space</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="upposted">metrics</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08416" assignment="upposted">relativity theory</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09317" assignment="upposted">space</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="14184" assignment="upposted">transformations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="10799" assignment="upposted">variations</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">We develop a non-perturbative formalism for scalar metric fluctuations from a 5D extended version of general relativity in vacuum. In this work we concentrate our efforts on calculations valid on large cosmological scales, which are dominant during the inflationary phase of the universe. The resulting metric in this limit is obtained after implementing a planar coordinate transformation on a 5D Ricci-flat metric solution. We calculate the spectrum of these fluctuations with an effective 4D Schwarzschild-de Sitter spacetime on cosmological scales, which is obtained after we make a static foliation on the non-compact extra coordinate. Our results show how the squared metric fluctuations of the primordial universe become scale invariant with the inflationary expansion. (orig.)</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>

metadata.@content: Stoica, Ovidiu Cristinel, E-mail: holotronix@gmail.com
On the Weyl curvature hypothesis
English
United States

Annals of Physics (New York); v. 338; ISSN 0003-4916; CODEN APNYA6; Nov 2013; p. 186-194; S0003-4916(13)00171-1; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.aop.2013.08.002; Copyright (c) 2013 Elsevier Science B.V., Amsterdam, The Netherlands, All rights reserved.; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (S71)
ANISOTROPY; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENTROPY; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEOMETRY; HYPOTHESIS; ISOTROPY; METRICS; SINGULARITY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; RELATIVITY THEORY; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES

The Weyl curvature hypothesis of Penrose attempts to explain the high homogeneity and isotropy, and the very low entropy of the early universe, by conjecturing the vanishing of the Weyl tensor at the Big-Bang singularity. In previous papers it has been proposed an equivalent form of Einsteins equation, which extends it and remains valid at an important class of singularities (including in particular the Schwarzschild, FLRW, and isotropic singularities). Here it is shown that if the Big-Bang singularity is from this class, it also satisfies the Weyl curvature hypothesis. As an application, we study a very general example of cosmological models, which generalizes the FLRW model by dropping the isotropy and homogeneity constraints. This model also generalizes isotropic singularities, and a class of singularities occurring in Bianchi cosmologies. We show that the Big-Bang singularity of this model is of the type under consideration, and satisfies therefore the Weyl curvature hypothesis. -- Highlights: The singularities we introduce are described by finite geometric/physical objects. Our singularities have smooth Riemann and Weyl curvatures. We show they satisfy Penroses Weyl curvature hypothesis (Weyl=0 at singularities). Examples: FLRW, isotropic singularities, an extension of Schwarzschilds metric. Example: a large class of singularities which may be anisotropic and inhomogeneous
January 2013

metadata.@content: Vacaru, Sergiu I. (Alexandru Ioan Cuza University, Rector's Office, Iasi (Romania); CERN, Theory Division, Geneva 23 (Switzerland))
Exact solutions in modified massive gravity and off-diagonal wormhole deformations
English
Germany
European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(3); ISSN 1434-6044; Mar 2014; p. 1-16; ;  Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-2781-y
Journal article
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)

ANISOTROPY; CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; DE SITTER SPACE; EFFECTIVE MASS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EXACT SOLUTIONS; FOUR-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; POLARIZATION; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SINGULARITY; SOLITONS; SPACE-TIME; THREE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; TRANSFORMATIONS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MASS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; METRICS; QUASI PARTICLES; RELATIVITY THEORY; SPACE

We explore off-diagonal deformations of 'prime' metrics in Einstein gravity (for instance, for wormhole configurations) into 'target' exact solutions in f(R,T)-modified and massive/bi-metric gravity theories. The new classes of solutions may, or may not, possess Killing symmetries and can be characterized by effective induced masses, anisotropic polarized interactions, and cosmological constants. For nonholonomic deformations with (conformal) ellipsoid/ toroid and/or solitonic symmetries and, in particular, for small eccentricity rotoid configurations, we can generate wormhole-like objects matching an external black ellipsoid--de Sitter geometries. We conclude that there are nonholonomic transforms and/or non-trivial limits to exact solutions in general relativity when modified/massive gravity effects are modeled by off-diagonal and/or nonholonomic parametric interactions. (orig.)
January 2014

metadata.@content: Rahaman, Farook; Bhar, Piyali (Jadavpur University, Department of Mathematics, Kolkata, West Bengal (India)); Biswas, Ritabrata (Indian Institute of Engineering Sceince and Technology Shibpur, Howrah, West Bengal (India)); Usmani, A.A. (Aligarh Muslim University, Department of Physics, Aligarh, Uttar Pradesh (India))
Exact interior solutions in 2 + 1-dimensional spacetime
English
Germany
European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(4); ISSN 1434-6044; Apr 2014; p. 1-7; ;  Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-2845-z
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

ANALYTIC FUNCTIONS; ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; EQUATIONS OF STATE; EXACT SOLUTIONS; FLUIDS; METRICS; RED SHIFT; SPACE-TIME; THREE-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS

We provide a new class of exact solutions for the interior in 2 + 1-dimensional spacetime. The solutions obtained for the perfect fluid model both with and without cosmological constant () are found to be regular and singularity free. It assumes very simple analytical forms that help us to study the various physical properties of the configuration. Solutions without  are found to be physically acceptable. (orig.)
January 2014

        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">We provide a new class of exact solutions for the interior in 2 + 1-dimensional spacetime. The solutions obtained for the perfect fluid model both with and without cosmological constant () are found to be regular and singularity free. It assumes very simple analytical forms that help us to study the various physical properties of the configuration. Solutions without  are found to be physically acceptable. (orig.)</abstract>

metadata.@content: Mazharimousavi, S.H.; Halilsoy, M.; Amirabi, Z. (Eastern Mediterranean University, Department of Physics, North Cyprus, Mersin 10 (Turkey))
Microscopic thin-shell wormholes in magnetic Melvin universe
English
Germany
European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(5); ISSN 1434-6044; May 2014; p. 1-8; ;  Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-2889-0
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMIC GASES; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; EQUATIONS OF STATE; LOCALITY; MAGNETIC FIELDS; METRICS; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; STABILITY; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUIDS; GASES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS

We construct thin-shell wormholes in the magnetic Melvin universe. It is shown that in order to make a TSW in the Melvin spacetime the radius of the throat cannot be larger than (2)/(B0), in which B0 is the magnetic field constant. We also analyze the stability of the constructed wormhole in terms of a linear perturbation around the equilibrium point. In our stability analysis we scan a full set of the Equation of States such as Linear Gas, Chaplygin Gas, Generalized Chaplygin Gas, Modified Generalized Chaplygin Gas, and Logarithmic Gas. Finally we extend our study to the wormhole solution in the unified Melvin and Bertotti-Robinson spacetime. In this extension we show that for some specific cases, the local energy density is partially positive but the total energy which supports the wormhole is positive. (orig.)
January 2014

metadata.@content: Garattini, Remo (Universita degli Studi di Bergamo, Facolta di Ingegneria, Dalmine, Bergamo (Italy); I.N.F.N.-sezione di Milano, Milan (Italy)); Lobo, Francisco S.N. (Centro de Astronomia e Astrofisica da Universidade de Lisboa, Lisbon (Portugal))
Gravity's Rainbow induces topology change
English
Germany
European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(5); ISSN 1434-6044; May 2014; p. 1-11; ;  Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-2884-5
Journal article
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)

EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; FEYNMAN DIAGRAM; FLUCTUATIONS; GRAVITONS; METRICS; MINKOWSKI SPACE; QUANTUM GRAVITY; SEMICLASSICAL APPROXIMATION; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; TOPOLOGY; VARIATIONAL METHODS; WAVE FUNCTIONS

APPROXIMATIONS; CALCULATION METHODS; DIAGRAMS; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; INFORMATION; MASSLESS PARTICLES; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; MATHEMATICS; POSTULATED PARTICLES; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RADIATIONS; SPACE; VARIATIONS

In this work, we explore the possibility that quantum fluctuations induce a topology change, in the context of Gravity's Rainbow. A semiclassical approach is adopted, where the graviton one-loop contribution to a classical energy in a background spacetime is computed through a variational approach with Gaussian trial wave functionals. The energy density of the graviton one-loop contribution, or equivalently the background spacetime, is then let to evolve, and consequently the classical energy is determined. More specifically, the background metric is fixed to be Minkowskian in the equation governing the quantum fluctuations, which behaves essentially as a backreaction equation, and the quantum fluctuations are let to evolve; the classical energy, which depends on the evolved metric functions, is then evaluated. Analyzing this procedure, a natural ultraviolet cutoff is obtained, which forbids the presence of an interior spacetime region, and this may result in a multiply connected spacetime. Thus, in the context of Gravity's Rainbow, this process may be interpreted as a change in topology, and in principle it results in the presence of a planckian wormhole. (orig.)
January 2014

metadata.@content: Bachas, C. (Laboratoire de Physique Theorique de l'Ecole Normale Superieure Unite mixte (UMR 8549) du CNRS et de l'ENS, Paris (France)); D'Hoker, E. (Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of California, Los Angeles, CA (United States)); Estes, J. (Blackett Laboratory, Imperial College, London (United Kingdom)); Krym, D. (Physics Department, New York City College of Technology, The City University of New York, Brooklyn, NY (United States))
M-theory solutions invariant under D(2,1; ) + D(2,1;)
English
Germany
Fortschritte der Physik (Online); v. 62(3); ISSN 1521-3978; 6 Mar 2014; p. 207-254; ;  Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/prop.201300039; With 6 figs., 2 tabs., 61 refs.
Journal article
PHYSICS OF ELEMENTARY PARTICLES AND FIELDS (S72)

ANTI DE SITTER SPACE; ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; BRANES; CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EUCLIDEAN SPACE; EXACT SOLUTIONS; GRADED LIE GROUPS; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LAGRANGE EQUATIONS; LAGRANGIAN FIELD THEORY; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; METRICS; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; STRING THEORY; SUPERGRAVITY; TOPOLOGY; TWO-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; UNIFIED GAUGE MODELS

DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; MATHEMATICS; M-THEORY; PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM FIELD THEORY; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE; SYMMETRY GROUPS; UNIFIED-FIELD THEORIES

We simplify and extend the construction of half-BPS solutions to 11-dimensional supergravity, with isometry superalgebra D(2,1;) + D(2,1;). Their space-time has the form AdS3 x S3 x S3 warped over a Riemann surface . It describes near-horizon geometries of M2 branes ending on, or intersecting with, M5 branes along a common string. The general solution to the BPS equations is specified by a reduced set of data (, h, G), where  is the real parameter of the isometry superalgebra, and h and G are functions on  whose differential equations and regularity conditions depend only on the sign of . The magnitude of  enters only through the map of h,G onto the supergravity fields, thereby promoting all solutions into families parametrized by vertical stroke  vertical stroke. By analyzing the regularity conditions for the supergravity fields, we prove two general theorems: (i) that the only solution with a 2-dimensional CFT dual is AdS3 x S3 x S3 x R 2, modulo discrete identifications of the flat R 2, and (ii) that solutions with  < 0 cannot have more than one asymptotic higher-dimensional AdS region. We classify the allowed singularities of h and G near the boundary of , and identify four local solutions: asymptotic AdS4/Z2 or AdS7' regions; highly-curved M5-branes; and a coordinate singularity called the ''cap''. By putting these ''Lego'' pieces together we recover all known global regular solutions with the above symmetry, including the self-dual strings on M5 for  <0, and the Janus solution for  > 0, but now promoted to families parametrized by vertical stroke  vertical stroke. We also construct exactly new regular solutions which are asymptotic to AdS4/Z2 for  < 0, and conjecture that they are a different superconformal limit of the self-dual string. Finally, we construct exactly  > 0 solutions with highly curved M5-brane regions, which are the formal continuation of the self-dual string solutions across the decompactification point at  = 0. Finally, we construct exactly  > 0 solutions with highly curved M5-brane regions, which are the formal continuation of the self-dual string solutions across the decompactification point at  = 0.         <descriptor type="valid" key="21631" assignment="upposted">partial differential equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="07195" assignment="upposted">particle models</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08123" assignment="upposted">quantum field theory</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08554" assignment="upposted">riemann space</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09317" assignment="upposted">space</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09721" assignment="upposted">symmetry groups</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="18029" assignment="upposted">unified-field theories</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">We simplify and extend the construction of half-BPS solutions to 11-dimensional supergravity, with isometry superalgebra D(2,1;) + D(2,1;). Their space-time has the form AdS<sub>3</sub> x S<sup>3</sup> x S<sup>3</sup> warped over a Riemann surface . It describes near-horizon geometries of M2 branes ending on, or intersecting with, M5 branes along a common string. The general solution to the BPS equations is specified by a reduced set of data (, h, G), where  is the real parameter of the isometry superalgebra, and h and G are functions on  whose differential equations and regularity conditions depend only on the sign of . The magnitude of  enters only through the map of h,G onto the supergravity fields, thereby promoting all solutions into families parametrized by vertical stroke  vertical stroke. By analyzing the regularity conditions for the supergravity fields, we prove two general theorems: (i) that the only solution with a 2-dimensional CFT dual is AdS<sub>3</sub> x S<sup>3</sup> x S<sup>3</sup> x R <sup>2</sup>, modulo discrete identifications of the flat R <sup>2</sup>, and (ii) that solutions with  < 0 cannot have more than one asymptotic higher-dimensional AdS region. We classify the allowed singularities of h and G near the boundary of , and identify four local solutions: asymptotic AdS<sub>4</sub>/Z<sub>2</sub> or AdS<sub>7</sub>' regions; highly-curved M5-branes; and a coordinate singularity called the ''cap''. By putting these ''Lego'' pieces together we recover all known global regular solutions with the above symmetry, including the self-dual strings on M5 for  <0, and the Janus solution for  > 0, but now promoted to families parametrized by vertical stroke  vertical stroke. We also construct exactly new regular solutions which are asymptotic to AdS<sub>4</sub>/Z<sub>2</sub> for  < 0, and conjecture that they are a different superconformal limit of the self-dual string. Finally, we construct exactly  > 0 solutions with highly curved M5-brane regions, which are the formal continuation of the self-dual string solutions across the decompactification point at  = 0. (Copyright copyright 2014 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH and Co. KGaA, Weinheim)</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>

metadata.@content: Fiol, Bartomeu; Garriga, Jaume (Departament de Fsica Fonamental i, Institut de Cincies del Cosmos, Universitat de Barcelona, Mart i Franqus 1, 08028 Barcelona (Spain)), E-mail: bfiol@ub.edu, E-mail: jaume.garriga@ub.edu
Semiclassical unimodular gravity
English
United States

Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2010(08); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 Aug 2010; p. 015; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2010/08/015; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

BLACK HOLES; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENTROPY; EUCLIDEAN SPACE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; METRICS; PATH INTEGRALS; SEMICLASSICAL APPROXIMATION; SPACE-TIME
APPROXIMATIONS; CALCULATION METHODS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INTEGRALS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; RELATIVITY THEORY; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES

Classically, unimodular gravity is known to be equivalent to General Relativity (GR), except for the fact that the effective cosmological constant  has the status of an integration constant. Here, we explore various formulations of unimodular gravity beyond the classical limit. We first consider the non-generally covariant action formulation in which the determinant of the metric is held fixed to unity. We argue that the corresponding quantum theory is also equivalent to General Relativity for localized perturbative processes which take place in generic backgrounds of infinite volume (such as asymptotically flat spacetimes). Next, using the same action, we calculate semiclassical non-perturbative quantities, which we expect will be dominated by Euclidean instanton solutions. We derive the entropy/area ratio for cosmological and black hole horizons, finding agreement with GR for solutions in backgrounds of infinite volume, but disagreement for backgrounds with finite volume. In deriving the above results, the path integral is taken over histories with fixed 4-volume. We point out that the results are different if we allow the 4-volume of the different histories to vary over a continuum range. In this ''generalized'' version of unimodular gravity, one recovers the full set of Einstein's equations in the classical limit, including the trace, so  is no longer an integration constant. Finally, we consider the generally covariant theory due to Henneaux and Teitelboim, which is classically equivalent to unimodular gravity. In this case, the standard semiclassical GR results are recovered provided that the boundary term in the Euclidean action is chosen appropriately

theory due to Henneaux and Teitelboim, which is classically equivalent to unimodular gravity. In this case, the standard semiclassical GR results are recovered provided that the boundary term in the Euclidean action is chosen appropriately
January 2010

metadata.@content: Qiu, Taotao; Yang, Kwei-Chou (Department of Physics, Chung-Yuan Christian University, Chung-Pei Rd. 200, Chung-li, 320 Taiwan (China)), E-mail: qiutt@mail.ihep.ac.cn, E-mail: kcyang@cycu.edu.tw
Perturbations in matter bounce with non-minimal coupling
English
United States

Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2010(11); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 Nov 2010; p. 012; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2010/11/012; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)
ASTROPHYSICS; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; COSMOLOGY; COUPLING; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; METRICS
EQUATIONS; EVALUATION; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; PHYSICS

In this paper, we investigate the perturbations in matter bounce induced from Lee-Wick lagrangian with the involvement of non-minimal coupling to the Einstein Gravity. We find that this extra non-minimal coupling term can cause a red-tilt on the primordial metric perturbation at extremely large scales. It can also lead to large enhancement of reheating of the normal field particles compared to the usual minimal coupling models
January 2010

metadata.@content: Brown, Iain A.; Hammami, Amir (Institute of Theoretical Astrophysics, University of Oslo, P.O. Box 1029 Blindern, N-0315 Oslo (Norway)), E-mail: ibrown@astro.uio.no, E-mail: amirham@astro.uio.no
Gauge issues in extended gravity and f(R) cosmology
English
United States

Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2012(04); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 Apr 2012; p. 002; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2012/04/002; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)
ASTROPHYSICS; CONFORMAL MAPPING; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GRAVITATION; NUMERICAL SOLUTION
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MAPPING; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; PHYSICS; TOPOLOGICAL MAPPING; TRANSFORMATIONS

We consider issues related to the conformal mapping between the Einstein and Jordan frames in f(R) cosmology. We consider the impact of the conformal transformation on the gauge of a perturbed system and show that unless the system is written in a restricted set of gauges the mapping could produce an inconsistent result in the target frame. Newtonian gauge lies within the restricted group but synchronous gauge does not. If this is not treated carefully it could in principle contaminate numerical calculations
January 2012

metadata.@content: Abdolrahimi, Shohreh; Catton, Cline; Page, Don N.; Yaghoobpour-Tari, Shima (Department of Physics, 4-181 CCIS, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta T6G 2E1 (Canada)), E-mail: abdolrah@ualberta.ca, E-mail: celine.cattoen-gilbert@canterbury.ac.nz, E-mail: dpage@ualberta.ca, E-mail: yaghoobp@ualberta.ca
Spectral methods in general relativity and large Randall-Sundrum II black holes
English
United States

Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics; v. 2013(06); ISSN 1475-7516; 1 Jun 2013; p. 039; ;  Available from http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2013/06/039; Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)
APPROXIMATIONS; BLACK HOLES; COMPARATIVE EVALUATIONS; COSMOLOGICAL CONSTANT; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENTROPY; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; MASS; NUMERICAL SOLUTION; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC
CALCULATION METHODS; EQUATIONS; EVALUATION; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; METRICS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; RELATIVITY THEORY; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES

Using a novel numerical spectral method, we have found solutions for large static Randall-Sundrum II (RSII) black holes by perturbing a numerical AdS5-CFT4 solution to the Einstein equation with a negative cosmological constant  that is asymptotically conformal to the Schwarzschild metric. We used a numerical spectral method independent of the Ricci-DeTurck-flow method used by Figueras, Lucietti, and Wiseman for a similar numerical solution. We have compared our black-hole solution to the one Figueras and Wiseman have derived by perturbing their numerical AdS5-CFT4 solution, showing that our solution agrees closely with theirs. We have obtained a closed-form approximation to the metric of the black hole on the brane. We have also deduced the new results that to first order in 1/(M2), the Hawking temperature and entropy of an RSII static black hole have the same values as the Schwarzschild metric with the same mass, but the horizon area is increased by about 4.7/()
January 2013

      </creators>

      </identifiers>

        <copies>
          <copy href="http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2013/06/039">http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1475-7516/2013/06/039</copy>
        </copies>
      </availability>
      <notes>
        <note>Country of input: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)</note>
      </notes>
      <is-part-of>
        <journal>
          <titles>
            <title type="primary">Journal of Cosmology and Astroparticle Physics</title>
          </titles>
          <identifiers>
            <identifier type="issn">1475-7516</identifier>
          </identifiers>
          <physical-description>v. 2013(06)</physical-description>
        </journal>
      </is-part-of>
    </publication>
    <classification>
      <categories>
        <category type="common" level="primary" key="S79">ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY</category>
      </categories>
      <descriptors>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="31809" assignment="indexer">approximations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="01114" assignment="indexer">black holes</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11539" assignment="indexer">comparative evaluations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="22241" assignment="indexer">cosmological constant</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02278" assignment="indexer">cosmology</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03130" assignment="indexer">entropy</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03915" assignment="indexer">general relativity theory</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="05885" assignment="indexer">mass</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="06858" assignment="indexer">numerical solution</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08872" assignment="indexer">schwarzschild metric</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="25063" assignment="upposted">calculation methods</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="23507" assignment="upposted">evaluation</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11351" assignment="upposted">field theories</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="31383" assignment="upposted">mathematical solutions</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="11472" assignment="upposted">metrics</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="07447" assignment="upposted">physical properties</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="08416" assignment="upposted">relativity theory</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="10060" assignment="upposted">thermodynamic properties</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">Using a novel numerical spectral method, we have found solutions for large static Randall-Sundrum II (RSII) black holes by perturbing a numerical AdS<sub>5</sub>-CFT<sub>4</sub> solution to the Einstein equation with a negative cosmological constant  that is asymptotically conformal to the Schwarzschild metric. We used a numerical spectral method independent of the Ricci-DeTurck-flow method used by Figueras, Lucietti, and Wiseman for a similar numerical solution. We have compared our black-hole solution to the one Figueras and Wiseman have derived by perturbing their numerical AdS<sub>5</sub>-CFT<sub>4</sub> solution, showing that our solution agrees closely with theirs. We have obtained a closed-form approximation to the metric of the black hole on the brane. We have also deduced the new results that to first order in 1/(M<sup>2</sup>), the Hawking temperature and entropy of an RSII static black hole have the same values as the Schwarzschild metric with the same mass, but the horizon area is increased by about 4.7/()</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>
    <administratives>
      <input-center type="subj" key="US">United States</input-center>
      <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights>
    </administratives>
  </record>
</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: Bampi, F.; Cianci, R. (Genoa Univ. (Italy). Ist. Matematico)
Comments on limits of space-times
United States
International Journal of Theoretical Physics; v. 19(3) p. 211-215; ISSN 0020-7748; Mar 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; LIMITING VALUES; METRICS; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

A coordinate-dependent investigation of limits of space-times is given. Different kinds of limits are found and analyzed. A criterion selecting limits which appear to be nothing but 'technical tricks' is proposed. Finally, a method for generating new limits from a given family of metrics is examined. (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Novello, M. (Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Fisicas, Rio de Janeiro, Brasil); d'Olival, J.B.S. (Instituto de Fisica, Rio de Janeiro, Brasil)
Nonlinear viscous cosmology
Poland
Acta Physica Polonica. Series B; v. 11(1) p. 3-13; ISSN 0587-4254; Jan 1980
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500); CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; DEFORMATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; HYDRODYNAMICS; NONLINEAR PROBLEMS; STOKES LAW; VISCOSITY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUID MECHANICS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS

We treat the galactic fluid, in the early epochs of the Universe, as a nonlinear Stokesian fluid. Some general comments on fluids with viscosity are made. Then we examine an exact solution and give a qualitative analysis for a Bianchi type-I cosmological model generated by a fluid whose viscosity depends quadratically on the deformation tensor. (author)
January 1980

        <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="04547" assignment="indexer">hydrodynamics</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="06761" assignment="indexer">nonlinear problems</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09509" assignment="indexer">stokes law</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="10860" assignment="indexer">viscosity</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor>

        <descriptor type="valid" key="05945" assignment="upposted">mechanics</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">We treat the galactic fluid, in the early epochs of the Universe, as a nonlinear Stokesian fluid. Then we examine an exact solution and give a qualitative analysis for a Bianchi type-I cosmological model generated by a fluid whose viscosity depends quadratically on the deformation tensor. (author)</abstract>

metadata.@content: Tipler, F.J. (Center for Theoretical Physics, University of Texas, Austin, Texas 78712)
Singularities from colliding plane gravitational waves
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 22(12) p. 2929-2932; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 Dec 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COLLISIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; METRICS; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES

A simple geometrical argument is given which shows that a collision between two plane gravitational waves must result in singularities. The argument suggests that these singularities are a peculiar feature of plane waves, because singularities are also a consequence of a collision between self-gravitating plane waves of other fields with arbitrarily small energy density
January 1980

metadata.@content: Cooperstock, F.I.; Sarracino, R.S.; Bayin, S.S. (Victoria Univ., British Columbia (Canada). Dept. of Physics)
The localisation of energy in general relativity
United Kingdom
Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 14(1) p. 181-189; ISSN 0305-4470; Jan 1981
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY; ENERGY TRANSFER; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATION; LOCALITY; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION
CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

The energy localisation in the case of spherical symmetry advanced previously is justified in reference to an exact interior solution which is a generalisation of the rho = constant Schwarzschild solution. This reveals the inadequacy of the Tolman expression for localisation which also fails to provide the correct total mass for a system which exhibits certain discontinuities. A generalised localisation expression for arbitrary static systems is proposed for further consideration. (author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Schaefer, G.; Dehnen, H. (Fakultaet fuer Physik der Universitaet Konstanz, D-7750 Konstanz, Postfach 5560, West Germany)
Gravitational radiation by the thermal phonons of a solid
United States
Physical Review. D, Particles Fields; v. 23(10) p. 2129-2136; ISSN 0556-2821; 15 May 1981
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
BLACKBODY RADIATION; CROSS SECTIONS; CYLINDERS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY SPECTRA; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; METRICS; NEUTRON STARS; PHONONS; TENSORS; THERMODYNAMIC PROPERTIES
ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; PHYSICAL PROPERTIES; QUASI PARTICLES; RADIATIONS; SPECTRA; STARS

Gravitational radiation by the phonons of a freely vibrating thin elastic cylinder is calculated in the high-frequency limit. For thermal excitation of the phonons the spectral energy distribution is found to be a blackbody one multiplied by the small opalescence factor (32/105)(MG/c2R)(c0/c)3. With the help of thermodynamic equilibrium considerations the resonance integral for the absorption cross section of the cylinder is deduced in the high-frequency limit. The application of the result to a neutron star is discussed
January 1981

metadata.@content: Aichelburg, P.C.; Gueven, R.
Vienna Univ. (Austria). Inst. fuer Theoretische Physik
Can charged black holes have a superhair
Austria
Report
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)

BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN-MAXWELL EQUATIONS; ELECTRIC CHARGES; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; KERR FIELD; KERR METRIC; O GROUPS; RARITA-SCHWINGER THEORY; SPACE-TIME; SUPERGRAVITY; SUPERSYMMETRY
DYNAMICAL GROUPS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; METRICS; SYMMETRY; SYMMETRY GROUPS

The spin 3/2 perturbations of the Kerr-Newman black holes are analyzed by linearizing the field equations of O(2) extended supergravity with respect to the spin 3/2 fields. The equations governing the spin 3/2 fields in Kerr-Newman geometry are decoupled and separated. All solutions that cannot be brought to zero by the supersymmetry transformations are shown to satisfy the generalized s = +- 3/2 Teukolsky equations. The stationary solutions of these equations are not regular and hence cannot provide a new hair for the black holes. This generalizes the previous results obtained for the uncharged rotating black holes. However, it is also pointed out that the particular case where the electric charge equals the mass must be excluded from the argument. (Auth.)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Oliveira, C.G.; Letelier, P.S.
Brasilia Univ. (Brazil). Dept. de Fisica
Field strenght copies in general relativity
Brazil
nd; 15 p; INIS-MF--7396
Miscellaneous
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GAUGE INVARIANCE; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; METRICS; SO-3 GROUPS; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; SO GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

Considering the SO(3,1) local, internal, transformations as the gauge group of general relativity, the possibility of having different affine connections (potentials) generating the same internal curvature (field strenght) is studied. Explicit examples of 'copies' are exhibited. The possibility to extend the concept of 'copy' to more general geometries is discussed. (Author)

metadata.@content: Reboucas, M.J. (Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Fisicas, Rio de Janeiro); Lima, A.S. de (Rio Grande do Norte Univ., Natal (Brazil). Dept. de Fisica)
Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Fisicas, Rio de Janeiro
Time-dependent, finite, rotating universes
Brazil
Report
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; ROTATION; TIME DEPENDENCE; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

Three new classes of finite, homogeneous and nonsingular solutions of Einstein's equations which have time-dependent expansion, shear and rotation are presented. The t-constant sections are of Bianchi type IX. The source of these geometries is a fluid which has not been thermalized. (Author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Beig, R.; Simon, W. (Vienna Univ. (Austria). Inst. fuer Theoretische Physik)
On the multipole expansion for stationary space-times
United Kingdom
Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series A, Mathematical and Physical Sciences; v. 376(1765) p. 333-341; ISSN 0080-4630; 14 May 1981
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EXPANSION; MULTIPOLES; SPACE-TIME; SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION
DISTRIBUTION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

It is proved that a stationary, asymptotically flat space-time is (in a precise sense) analytic in a neighbourhood of spatial infinity. This implies that there exists a multipole expansion. Its terms are shown to be uniquely determined by the Geroch-Hansen multipole moments. (author)
January 1981

metadata.@content: Rauch, R.; Shaw, J.C.; Nieh, H.-T. (State Univ. of New York, Stony Brook (USA). Inst. for Theoretical Physics)
Birkhoff's theorem for ghost-free, tachyon-free R+R2+Q2 theories with torsion
United States
General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 14(4) p. 331-354; ISSN 0001-7701; Apr 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; P INVARIANCE; SCALARS; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SO-3 GROUPS; SPACE-TIME; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; TACHYONS; TORSION
CONFIGURATION; ELEMENTARY PARTICLES; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; LIE GROUPS; METRICS; POSTULATED PARTICLES; SO GROUPS; SYMMETRY GROUPS

The conditions under which the class of ghost-free, tachyon-free R+R2+Q2 theories with torsion satisfy Birkhoff's theorem are investigated. A weakened Birkhoff theorem is proved requiring an additional assumption of parity invariance for two Lagrangians one of which contains torsion squared terms in addition to curvature squared terms. For another Lagrangian, also containing torsion squared terms, a weakened Birkhoff theorem requiring the additional assumptions is shown to satisfy a weakened Birkhoff theorem requiring only the additional assumption of constant scalar curvature. In addition the explicit dependence of torsion on parity noninvariant quantities is displayed. (author)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Stewart, B.W. (Thomas More Coll., Fort Mitchell, KY (USA). Dept. of Physics)
Conformally flat, anisotropic spheres in general relativity
United Kingdom
Journal of Physics. A, Mathematical and General; v. 15(8) p. 2419-2427; ISSN 0305-4470; Aug 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANISOTROPY; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY; FLUIDS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; LINEAR MOMENTUM; ROTATION; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC; SPHERES; SYMMETRY; TENSORS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

Anisotropic (principal stresses unequal), conformally flat, spherically symmetric interior solutions are examined. The properties of several solutions are compared with those of the conformally flat Schwarzschild interior. (author)

metadata.@content: Denardo, G. (Trieste Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica Teorica; Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Trieste (Italy)); Spallucci, E. (Trieste Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica Teorica)
Observer-dependent effects in a uniform electrovacuum space-time
Italy
Lettere al Nuovo Cimento; v. 23(6) p. 223-226; ISSN 0024-1318; 7 Oct 1978
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
COORDINATES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; LIGHT CONE; SPACE-TIME; TRANSFORMATIONS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

The physical meaning of a uniform electrovacuum metric is discussed. In particular, it is shown that the presence of a thermal spectrum is a purely observer-dependent effect. It is also obtained a coordinate transformation which cancels it and changes the metric into the usual form of the Bertotti Robinson space-time. (author)
January 1978

metadata.@content: Dobiasch, P.; Maison, D. (Max-Planck-Institut fuer Physik und Astrophysik, Muenchen (Germany, F.R.))
Stationary, spherically symmetric solutions of Jordan's unified theory of gravity and electromagnetism
United States
General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 14(3) p. 231-242; ISSN 0001-7701; Mar 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; BLACK HOLES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTRIC CHARGES; ELECTROMAGNETISM; GRAVITATION; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; MASS; SPACE-TIME; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; SYMMETRY
CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MAGNETISM

All stationary, spherically symmetric solutions of Jordan's unified theory of gravity and electromagnetism are constructed. Conditions for the solutions are given to represent black holes with nonvanishing mass, electric and magnetic charge. (author)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Spokoiny, B.L. (AN SSSR, Moscow. Inst. Teoreticheskoj Fiziki)
The effect of the electromagnetic fields on the evolution of homogeneous cosmological models near the singularity
United States
General Relativity and Gravitation; v. 14(3) p. 279-291; ISSN 0001-7701; Mar 1982
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS; FLUIDS; METRICS; OSCILLATIONS; ROTATION; SINGULARITY
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

Homogeneous cosmological models of all Bianchi types with a general (nondiagonal) metric are considered near the singularity. The spaces are filled with an arbitrary sourceless six-component electromagnetic field (EMF) and a perfect fluid at rest. It is shown that in the general case the models of types VI0, VII0, VIII, and IX have an oscillatory regime. The models of all the other types have Kasner asymptotics. The main result of the present paper is the derivation of the law of rotation of the Kasner axes. (author)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Isenberg, J. (California Univ., Berkeley (USA). Dept. of Mathematics); Moncrief, V. (Yale Univ., New Haven, CT (USA). Dept. of Physics)
The existence of constant mean curvature foliations of Gowdy 3-tours spacetimes
Germany
Communications in Mathematical Physics; v. 86(4) p. 485-494; ISSN 0010-3616; Oct 1982
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS; RIEMANN SPACE; SPACE-TIME; SURFACES; TOPOLOGY; TOROIDAL CONFIGURATION
ANNULAR SPACE; CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; MATHEMATICS; SPACE

We consider the class of smooth, maximally extended, globally hyperbolic, vacuum, Gowdy spacetimes on T3xR and prove that these spacetimes are globally foliated by space-like, constant mean curvature hypersurfaces. Our results can easily be extended to cover electrovac solutions of the same symmetry type and can probably be extended to cover other spacetime topologies as well. (orig.)
January 1982

metadata.@content: Frieman, J.A.; Will, C.M. (Institute of Theoretical Physics, Stanford University)
Evolution of perturbations in an inflationary universe
United States
Astrophysical Journal; v. 259(2) p. 437-441; ISSN 0004-637X; 15 Aug 1982
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1500)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY DENSITY; QUANTUM MECHANICS; RELATIVITY THEORY; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS

We analyze the evolution of inhomogeneous density perturbations in a model of the very early universe that is dominated for a time by a constant energy density of a false quantum-mechanical vacuum, with rho/sub v/approx.(1015 GeV/k)4. During this period, the universe inflates exponentially and supercools exponentially, until a phase transition back to the true vacuum reheats the matter and radiation. We focus on the physically measurable, coordinate-independent modes of inhomogeneous perturbations of this model and find that all modes either are constant or are exponentially damped during the inflationary era
January 1982
