metadata.@content: Calvani, M. (Padua Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Astronomia); Turolla, R. (International School for Advanced Studies, Trieste (Italy))
Singularities in the delta = 3 Tomimatsu-Sato space-time
Italy
Lettere al Nuovo Cimento; v. 28(14) p. 492-496; ISSN 0024-1318; 2 Aug 1980
Journal article
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1100)
ANGULAR MOMENTUM; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL COLLAPSE; KERR METRIC; MASS; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; METRICS

The existence of singularities outside the equatorial plane is investigated. We show that when the specific angular momentum a exceeds the mass m of the source, there are six ring singularities, while when a<m the singularities lie only in the equatorial plane. (author)
January 1980

metadata.@content: Brill, D.R. (Maryland Univ., College Park (USA). Dept. of Physics and Astronomy)
On spacetimes without maximal surfaces
Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands
Hu Ning (ed.); 904 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 79-87; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120); ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEODESICS; METRICS; SPACE-TIME; TOPOLOGY; UNIVERSE
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; MATHEMATICS

Whereas asymptotically flat spacetimes are usually assumed to admit a spacelike maximal Cauchy hypersurface, it is shown that such hypersurfaces do not always exist, by giving explicit counter-examples. (Auth.)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Herrera, L.; Jimenez, J. (Universidad Central de Venezuela, Caracas. Dept. de Fisica)
The complexification of a non-rotating sphere: an extension of the Newman-Janis algorithm
Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands
Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 1017-1022; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ALGORITHMS; BOUNDARY CONDITIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; KERR METRIC; SCHWARZSCHILD METRIC
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; METRICS

Since the discovery of the Kerr metric there have been many attempts to find a matter distribution that could be matched to it. With this aim the authors employ a procedure given by Newman and Janis, by means of which one can derive the Kerr metric from the Schwarzschild metric. The procedure is applied to a spherical symmetric metric which contains the internal Schwarzschild solution for a perfect fluid as a special case. The new metric can be matched at the surface of the source to the exterior Kerr metric. (Auth.)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Zhu Shichang (Department of Physics, Shanghai Teachers College, China)
The expansion of void inhomogeneous cosmological model
Proceedings of the third Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity
Netherlands
Hu Ning (ed.); 641 p; ISBN 0-444-86746-5; 1983; p. 1391-1398; North-Holland; Amsterdam (Netherlands); 3. Marcel Grossmann meeting on general relativity; Shanghai (China); 30 Aug - 3 Sep 1982
Book
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; EXPANSION; MASS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

The low-density region in Tolman inhomogeneous cosmic model is called Tolman void. In this paper the expansions of mass invariable void and mass variable void are discussed respectively. The conclusion is that the expansion parameter of Tolman void is smaller than Hubble parameter of cosmological background. (Auth.)
January 1983

metadata.@content: Finn, L.S. (California Inst. of Tech., Pasadena (USA))
g-modes of non-radially pulsating relativistic stars: the slow-motion formalism
United Kingdom
Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society; v. 222(2) p. 393-416; ISSN 0035-8711; CODEN MNRAA; 15 Sep 1986
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1530)
EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FLUID MECHANICS; GRAVITATIONAL RADIATION; NEUTRON STARS; PULSATING VARIABLE STARS; PULSATIONS; RELATIVISTIC RANGE; STAR MODELS
ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS; RADIATIONS; STARS; VARIABLE STARS

A new formalism, designed explicitly for the numerical study of g-modes of non-rotating, perfect-fluid, relativistic stars, is presented. The formalism is based on the analysis of Thorne and Campolattaro, (1967, Astrophys. J., 149,591) but with: (i) a choice of perturbation variables more suited to the numerical analysis of the low-frequency g-mode pulsations, (ii) the introduction of an instantaneous-gravity approximation that replaces the boundary condition of outgoing gravitational radiation at infinity by a non-radiative, Newtonian-like boundary condition, and (iii) an energy principle for determining the damping time of a mode due to gravitational radiation. The new formalism is applied to the study of g-mode pulsations of neutron star models with a polytropic equation of state. (author)
January 1986

metadata.@content: Logunov, A.A.; Loskutov, Yu.M.
Gosudarstvennyj Komitet po Ispol'zovaniyu Atomnoj Ehnergii SSSR, Serpukhov. Inst. Fiziki Vysokikh Ehnergij
Relativistic theory of gravitation and nonuniqueness of the predictions of general relativity theory
USSR
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)

ANGULAR MOMENTUM; CONSERVATION LAWS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; FUNDAMENTAL CONSTANTS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GEODESICS; GRAVITATION; GRAVITATIONAL FIELDS; LAGRANGIAN FUNCTION; MINKOWSKI SPACE; RED SHIFT; RELATIVISTIC RANGE; TEST PARTICLES; UNCERTAINTY PRINCIPLE
ENERGY RANGE; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL SPACE; SPACE; TENSORS

It is shown that while the predictions of relativistic theory of gravitation (RTG) for the gravitational effects are unique and consistent with the experimental data available, the relevant predictions of general relativity theory are not unique. Therewith the above nonuniqueness manifests itself in some effects in the first order in the gravitational interaction constant in others in the second one. The absence in GRT of the energy-momentum and angular momentum conservation laws for the matter and gravitational field taken together and its inapplicability to give uniquely determined predictions for the gravitational phenomena compel to reject GRT as a physical theory
January 1986

metadata.@content: Barut, A.O.; Meystre, P. (Max planck Institute, Garching)
A classical model of EPR experiment with quantum mechanical correlations and Bell inequalities
Frontiers of nonequilibrium statistical physics
United States

Moore, G.T.; Scully, M.O; p. 139-143; 1986; p. 139-143; Plenum Press; New York, NY (USA); NATO advanced study institute on nonequilibrium quantum statistical mechanics; Santa Fe, NM (USA); 3-16 Jun 1984
Book
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1110)
BELL THEOREM; CLASSICAL MECHANICS; CORRELATION FUNCTIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; HIDDEN VARIABLES; PARTICLE MODELS; QUANTUM MECHANICS; STATISTICAL MECHANICS; WAVE FUNCTIONS
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNCTIONS; MATHEMATICAL MODELS; MECHANICS

This paper presents a simple model of a classical break-up process in which the correlation E(a,b) of the components A and B of the spins of the to subsystems along directions a and b gives precisely the quantum mechanical result - cos(a /SUP ./ b). The model is ''local'', but the normalization procedure of correlation functions in terms of hidden variables is different from that used in deriving Bell's inequalities. A discretization procedure of the classical spins is given which reproduces fully the dichotomous quantum mechanical results both for probabilities and for correlation functions. This procedure illustrates clearly the difference between quantum and classical spins and provides a possible intuitive picture for the notion of the reduction of the wave function
January 1986

metadata.@content: Casas, J.A.; Martin, C.P.; Vozmediano, A.H. (Universidad Autonoma de Madrid (Spain). Dept. de Fisica Teorica)
Experimental tests of extra dimensions
Netherlands
Phys. Lett., B; v. 186(1) p. 29-32; ISSN 0370-2693; CODEN PYLBA; 26 Feb 1987
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)

ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CANONICAL DIMENSION; COUPLING CONSTANTS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; FUNDAMENTAL CONSTANTS; GENERAL RELATIVITY THEORY; GRAVITATIONAL INTERACTIONS; MANY-DIMENSIONAL CALCULATIONS; SPHERICAL CONFIGURATION; TESTING
BASIC INTERACTIONS; CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; FIELD THEORIES; SCALE DIMENSION

Spherically symmetric solutions of general relativity in higher dimensions are tested. We find that the existence of extra dimensions is compatible with the classical tests of general relativity, which place almost no restrictions on the parameters involved. The models studied fail to explain the geological data concerning the apparent variability of the gravitational constant with the distance. (orig.)
January 1987

metadata.@content: Kofman, L.A. (AN Ehstonskoj SSR, Tartu. Inst. Astrofiziki i Fiziki Atmosfery); Mukhanov, V.F. (AN SSSR, Moscow. Inst. Yadernykh Issledovanij)
Evolution of disturbances in inflationary Universe
Ehvolyutsiya vozmushchenij v inflyatsionnoj Vselennoj
Russian
USSR
Pis'ma v Zhurnal Ehksperimental'noj i Teoreticheskoj Fiziki; v. 44(11) p. 481-483; ISSN 0370-274X; CODEN PZETA; 10 Dec 1986; For English translation see the journal JETP Letters (USA).
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
CONFORMAL INVARIANCE; DISTURBANCES; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATION; INFLATIONARY UNIVERSE; METRICS
COSMOLOGICAL MODELS; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; INVARIANCE PRINCIPLES; MATHEMATICAL MODELS

The problem of the behaviour of the Universe metrics scalar disturbances in the gravitation theory with higher derivatives is solved. It is shown that heterogeneities generated from quantum flutuations can prove to be sufficient for the formation of galaxies. Restrictions for the theory parameters resulting from observations are found
January 1986

metadata.@content: Chandrasekhar, Subrahmanyan (Chicago Univ., IL (USA)); Ferrari, Valeria (Rome Univ. (Italy). Ist. di Fisica)
On the dispersion of cylindrical impulsive gravitational waves
United Kingdom
Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series A, Mathematical and Physical Sciences; v. 412(1842) p. 75-91; ISSN 0080-4630; CODEN PRLAA; 8 Jul 1987
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (A1550)
ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; CYLINDRICAL CONFIGURATION; DISPERSION RELATIONS; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GRAVITATIONAL WAVES; PULSES; REFLECTION; SHOCK WAVES; SINGULARITY; WAVE PACKETS
CONFIGURATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

An exact solution, describing the dispersion of a wave packet of gravitational radiation, having initially (at time t = O) an impulsive character, is analysed. The impulsive character of the wave-packet derives from the space-time being flat, except at a radial distance  = 1 (say) at t O, and the time-derivative of the Weyl scalars exhibiting delta-function singularities at =1, when t  O. The principal feature of the dispersion is the development of a singularity of the metric function, v, and of the Weyl scalar, PSI2, when the wave, after reflection at the centre, collides with the still incoming waves. The evolution of the metric functions and of the Weyl scalars, as the dispersion progresses, is illustrated graphically. (author)
January 1987

metadata.@content: Mignemi, S. (International School of Advanced Studies, Trieste (Italy)); Wiltshire, D.L.
International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)
Spherically symmetric solutions in dimensionally reduced spacetimes
International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)
Report
CLASSICAL AND QUANTUM MECHANICS, GENERAL PHYSICS (A1120)
ASYMPTOTIC SOLUTIONS; COMPACTIFICATION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; SPACE-TIME
EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS

We study static solutions of the vacuum Einstein equations in D=m+n+2 dimensions which have the following symmetries; the solutions are spherically symmetric in (m+2) dimensions, (or more generally the m-sphere is replaced by any arbitrary m-dimensional Einstein space), while the internal space is an arbitrary n-dimensional Einstein space. The global properties of all such solutions are derived by considering the equivalent dimensionally reduced system in (m+2) dimensions, and by using techniques from the theory of dynamical systems after a judicious choice of variables. Apart from the trivial case of the Schwarzschild solution with constant scalar field all solutions are found to contain naked singularities or else not to be asymptotically flat; as would be expected from the ''no hair'' theorems. (author). 27 refs, 2 figs
January 1988

<html><head><META http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=UTF-8"/></head><body><inisrecord>
  <action trn="XA8924022" type="add" />
  <record role="document" source-system="fibre" trn="XA8924022" type="report" rn="20046821">
    <publication>
      <titles>
        <title type="primary" xml:lang="en">Spherically symmetric solutions in dimensionally reduced spacetimes</title>
      </titles>
      <date value="1988-12-" sici-chronology="198812">Dec 1988</date>
      <physical-description>24 p.</physical-description>
      <country key="XA">International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)</country>
      <creators and-others="no">
        <creator type="personal">Mignemi, S.</creator>
        <creator type="affiliation">International School of Advanced Studies, Trieste (Italy)</creator>
        <creator type="personal">Wiltshire, D.L.</creator>
        <creator type="corporate">International Centre for Theoretical Physics, Trieste (Italy)</creator>
      </creators>
      <identifiers>
        <identifier type="report-number">IC--88/416</identifier>
      </identifiers>
      <availability inis="yes">
        <contact>Available from INIS: http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:20046821</contact>
        <copies>
          <copy href="http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:20046821">http://inis.iaea.org/search/search.aspx?orig_q=RN:20046821</copy>
        </copies>
      </availability>
    </publication>
    <classification>
      <categories>
        <category type="common" level="primary" key="A1120" />
      </categories>
      <descriptors>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="00681" assignment="indexer">asymptotic solutions</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="23384" assignment="indexer">compactification</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="02921" assignment="indexer">einstein field equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="09323" assignment="indexer">space-time</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03150" assignment="upposted">equations</descriptor>
        <descriptor type="valid" key="03482" assignment="upposted">field equations</descriptor>
      </descriptors>
      <abstracts>
        <abstract content="available" xml:lang="en">We study static solutions of the vacuum Einstein equations in D=m+n+2 dimensions which have the following symmetries; the solutions are spherically symmetric in (m+2) dimensions, (or more generally the m-sphere is replaced by any arbitrary m-dimensional Einstein space), while the internal space is an arbitrary n-dimensional Einstein space. The global properties of all such solutions are derived by considering the equivalent dimensionally reduced system in (m+2) dimensions, and by using techniques from the theory of dynamical systems after a judicious choice of variables. Apart from the trivial case of the Schwarzschild solution with constant scalar field all solutions are found to contain naked singularities or else not to be asymptotically flat; as would be expected from the ''no hair'' theorems. (author). 27 refs, 2 figs</abstract>
      </abstracts>
    </classification>
    <administratives>
      <input-center type="subj" key="XA">International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA)</input-center>
      <rights held-by="inis">INIS</rights>
    </administratives>
  </record>
</inisrecord></body></html>

metadata.@content: Rahaman, Farook (Jadavpur University, Department of Mathematics, Kolkata, West Bengal (India)); Kuhfittig, P.K.F. (Milwaukee School of Engineering, Department of Mathematics, Milwaukee, WI (United States)); Ray, Saibal (Government College of Engineering and Ceramic Technology, Department of Physics, Kolkata, West Bengal (India)); Islam, Nasarul (Danga High Madrasah, Department of Mathematics, Kolkata, West Bengal (India))
Possible existence of wormholes in the galactic halo region
English
Germany
European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(2); ISSN 1434-6044; Feb 2014; p. 1-7; ;  Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-2750-5
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; ANISOTROPY; COSMOLOGY; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; ENERGY-MOMENTUM TENSOR; EQUILIBRIUM; METRICS; MILKY WAY; NONLUMINOUS MATTER; ROTATION; SCATTERING; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION; WAVE PROPAGATION
DISTRIBUTION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GALAXIES; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; MATTER; MOTION; TENSORS

Two observational results, the density profile from simulations performed in the CDM scenario and the observed flat galactic rotation curves, are taken as input with the aim of showing that the galactic halo possesses some of the characteristics needed to support traversable wormholes. This result should be sufficient to provide an incentive for scientists to seek observational evidence for wormholes in the galactic halo region. (orig.)
January 2014

metadata.@content: Kuhfittig, Peter K.F. (Milwaukee School of Engineering, Department of Mathematics, Milwaukee, WI (United States))
Gravitational lensing of wormholes in the galactic halo region
English
Germany
European Physical Journal. C; v. 74(3); ISSN 1434-6044; Mar 2014; p. 1-6; ;  Available from: http://dx.doi.org/10.1140/epjc/s10052-014-2818-2
Journal article
ASTROPHYSICS, COSMOLOGY AND ASTRONOMY (S79)

ANALYTICAL SOLUTION; EINSTEIN FIELD EQUATIONS; GALAXIES; GRAVITATIONAL LENSES; MAGELLANIC CLOUDS; METRICS; MILKY WAY; NONLUMINOUS MATTER; SINGULARITY; SPACE-TIME; SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION; VISIBLE RADIATION; WAVE PROPAGATION
DISTRIBUTION; ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION; EQUATIONS; FIELD EQUATIONS; GALAXIES; LENSES; MATHEMATICAL SOLUTIONS; MATTER; RADIATIONS

A recent study by Rahaman et al. has shown that the galactic halo possesses the necessary properties for supporting traversable wormholes, based on two observational results, the Navarro-Frenk-White density profile and the observed flat rotation curves of galaxies. Using a method for calculating the deflection angle pioneered by V. Bozza, it is shown that the deflection angle diverges at the throat of the wormhole. The resulting photon sphere has a radius of about 0.40 ly. Given the dark-matter background, detection may be possible from past data using ordinary light. (orig.)
January 2014
